The mechanism used for setting the watch is then connected,Irrelevant
This mechanism involves two pins that extend beyond the case of the watch,Irrelevant
One pin lets the counter circuit know which reading to reset—seconds minutes or hours,Irrelevant
The second pin is pushed a number of times to bring the display to the desired reading,Irrelevant
The entire circuit board along with a battery is then closed into a case and a wrist strap is attached,Relevant
Before consideration can be given to the construction of individual wind turbines manufacturers must determine a proper area for the siting of wind farms,Irrelevant
Winds must be consistent and their speed must be regularly over 155 miles per hour (25 kilometers per hour),Irrelevant
If the winds are stronger during certain seasons it is preferred that they be greatest during periods of maximum electricity use,Irrelevant
In Californias Altamont Pass for instance site of the worlds largest wind farm wind speed peaks in the summer when demand is high,Irrelevant
In some areas of New England where wind farms are being considered winds are strongest in the winter when the need for heating increases the consumption of electrical power,Irrelevant
Wind farms work best in open areas of slightly rolling land surrounded by mountains,Irrelevant

These areas are preferred because the wind turbines can be placed on ridges and remain unobstructed by trees and buildings and the mountains concentrate the air flow creating a natural wind tunnel of stronger faster winds,Irrelevant
Wind farms must also be placed near utility lines to facilitate the transfer of the electricity to the local power plant,Irrelevant
The nacelle is a strong hollow shell that contains the inner workings of the wind turbine such as the main drive shaft and the gearbox,Irrelevant
It also contains the blade pitch control a hydraulic system that controls the angle of the blades and the yaw drive which controls the position of the turbine relative to the wind,Irrelevant
A typical nacelle for a current turbine weighs approximately 22000 pounds,Irrelevant
Wherever a wind farm is to be built the roads are cut to make way for transporting parts,Relevant
At each wind turbine location the land is graded and the pad area is leveled,Relevant
A concrete foundation is then laid into the ground followed by the installation of the underground cables,Relevant

These cables connect the wind turbines to each other in series and also connect all of them to the remote control center where the wind farm is monitored and the electricity is sent to the power company,Relevant
Although the towers steel parts are manufactured off site in a factory they are usually assembled on site,Relevant
The parts are bolted together before erection and the tower is kept horizontal until placement,Relevant
A crane lifts the tower into position all bolts are tightened and stability is tested upon completion,Relevant
The fiberglass nacelle like the tower is manufactured off site in a factory,Irrelevant
Unlike the tower however it is also put together in the factory,Irrelevant
Its inner workings—main drive shaft gearbox and blade pitch and yaw controls—are assembled and then mounted onto a base frame,Irrelevant

The nacelle is then bolted The utility box for each wind turbine and the electrical communication system for the wind farm is installed simultaneously with the placement of the nacelle and blades,Relevant
Cables run from the nacelle to the utility box and from the utility box to the remote control center,Irrelevant
The utility box for each wind turbine and the electrical communication system for the wind farm is installed simultaneously with the placement of the nacelle and blades,Relevant
Cables run from the nacelle to the utility box and from the utility box to the remote control center around the equipment,Relevant
At the site the nacelle is lifted onto the completed tower and bolted into place,Relevant
Aluminum blades are created by bolting sheets of aluminum together while wooden blades are carved to form an aerodynamic propeller similar in crosssection to an airplane wing,Relevant
By far the greatest number of blades however are formed from fiberglass,Irrelevant
The manufacture of fiberglass is a painstaking operation,Irrelevant
First a mold that is in two halves like a clam shell yet shaped like a blade is prepared,Relevant
Next a fiberglassresin composite mixture is applied to the inner surfaces of the mold which is then closed,Relevant
The fiberglass mixture must then dry for several hours while it does an airfilled bladder within the mold helps the blade keep its shape,Relevant
After the fiberglass is dry the mold is then opened and the bladder is removed,Relevant
Final preparation of the blade involves cleaning sanding sealing the two halves and painting,Relevant
The blades are usually bolted onto the nacelle after it has been placed onto the tower,Irrelevant

Because assembly is easier to accomplish on the ground occasionally a threepronged blade has two blades bolted onto the nacelle before it is lifted and the third blade is bolted on after the nacelle is in place,Irrelevant
The utility box for each wind turbine and the electrical communication system for the wind farm is installed simultaneously with the placement of the nacelle and blades,Relevant
Cables run from the nacelle to the utility box and from the utility box to the remote control center,Relevant
The process of wine production has remained much the same throughout the ages but new sophisticated machinery and technology have helped streamline and increase the output of wine,Irrelevant
Whether such advances have enhanced the quality of wine is however a subject of debate,Irrelevant
These advances include a variety of mechanical harvesters grape crushers temperaturecontrolled tanks and centrifuges,Irrelevant
The procedures involved in creating wine are often times dictated by the grape and the amount and type of wine being produced,Irrelevant
Recipes for certain types of wine require the winemaker (the vintner) to monitor and regulate the amount of yeast the fermentation process and other steps of the process,Irrelevant
While the manufacturing process is highly automated in medium to largesized wineries small wineries still use hand operated presses and store wine in musty wine cellars,Irrelevant
A universal factor in the production of fine wine is timing,Irrelevant
This includes picking grapes at the right time removing the must at the right time monitoring and regulating fermentation and storing the wine long enough,Irrelevant
The winemaking process can be divided into four distinct steps harvesting and crushing grapes fermenting must ageing the wine and packaging,Irrelevant
Vineyardists inspect sample clusters of wine grapes with a refractometer to determine if the grapes are ready to be picked,Relevant
The refractometer is a small handheld device (the size of a miniature telescope) that allows the vineyardist to accurately check the amount of sugar in the grapes,Irrelevant
If the grapes are ready for picking a mechanical harvester (usually a suction picker) gathers and funnels the grapes into a field hopper or mobile storage container,Irrelevant
Some mechanical harvesters have grape crushers mounted on the machinery allowing vineyard workers to gather grapes and press them at the same time,Irrelevant
The result is that vineyards can deliver newly crushed grapes called must to wineries eliminating the need for crushing at the winery,Irrelevant
This also prevents oxidization of the juice through tears or splits in the grapes skins,Irrelevant
Mechanical harvesters or in some cases robots are now used in most medium to large vineyards thereby eliminating the need for handpicking,Irrelevant
First used in California vineyards in 1968 mechanical harvesters have significantly decreased the time it takes to gather grapes,Irrelevant
The harvesters have also allowed grapes to be gathered at night when they are cool fresh and ripe,Relevant
The field hoppers are transported to the winery where they are unloaded into a crusherstemmer machine,Relevant
Some crusherstemmer machines are hydraulic while others are driven by air pressure,Irrelevant
The grapes are crushed and the stems are removed leaving liquid must that flows either into a stainless steel fermentation tank or a wooden vat (for fine wines),Relevant
Once at the winery the grapes are crushed if necessary and the must is fermented settled clarified and filtered,Relevant
After filtering the wine is aged in stainless steel tanks or wooden vats,Relevant
White and rose wines may age for a year to four years or far less than a year,Irrelevant
Red wines may age for seven to ten years,Irrelevant

Most large wineries age their wine in large temperaturecontrolled stainless steel tanks that are above ground while smaller wineries may still store their wine in wooden barrels in damp wine cellars,Irrelevant
For white wine all the grape skins are separated from the must by filters or centrifuges before the must undergoes fermentation,Relevant
For red wine the whole crushed grape including the skin goes into the fermentation tank or vat,Relevant
(The pigment in the grape skins give red wine its color,Irrelevant
The amount of time the skins are left in the tank or vat determines how dark or light the color will be,Relevant
For rose the skins only stay in the tank or vat for a short time before they are filtered out,Relevant
During the fermentation process wild yeast are fed into the tank or vat to turn the sugar in the must into alcohol,Relevant
To add strength varying degrees of yeast may be added,Irrelevant
In addition cane or beet sugar may be added to increase the alcoholic content,Relevant
Adding sugar is call chaptalization,Irrelevant
Usually chaptalization is done because the grapes have not received enough sun prior to harvesting,Irrelevant
The winemaker will use a handheld hydrometer to measure the sugar content in the tank or vat,Irrelevant
The wine must ferments in the tank or vat for approximately seven to fourteen days depending on the type of wine being produced,Irrelevant
After crushing and fermentation wine needs to be stored filtered and properly aged,Relevant
In some instances the wine must also be blended with other alcohol,Irrelevant
Many wineries still store wine in damp subterranean wine cellars to keep the wine cool but larger wineries now store wine above ground in epoxylined and stainless steel tanks,Irrelevant
The tanks are temperaturecontrolled by water that circulates inside the lining of the tank shell,Irrelevant
Other similar tanks are used instead of the old redwood and concrete vats when wine is temporarily stored during the settling process,Irrelevant
After fermentation certain wines (mainly red wine) will be crushed again and pumped into another fermentation tank where the wine will ferment again for approximately three to seven days,Relevant
This is done not only to extend the wines shelf life but also to ensure clarity and color stability,Irrelevant
The wine is then pumped into settling (racking) tanks or vats,Relevant
The wine will remain in the tank for one to two months,Relevant
Typically racking is done at 50 to 60 degrees Fahrenheit (10 to 16 degrees Celsius) for red wine and 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius) for white wine,Irrelevant
After the initial settling (racking) process certain wines are pumped into another settling tank or vat where the wine remains for another two to three months,Relevant
During settling the weighty unwanted debris (remaining stem pieces etc) settle to the bottom of the tank and are eliminated when the wine is pumped into another tank,Relevant
The settling process creates smoother wine,Relevant
Additional settling may be necessary for certain wines,Irrelevant
After the settling process the wine passes through a number of filters or centrifuges where the wine is stored at low temperatures or where clarifying substances trickle through the wine,Relevant
After various filtering processes the wine is aged in stainless steel tanks or wooden vats,Relevant
White and rose wines may age for a year to four years or far less than a year,Irrelevant
Red wines may age for seven to ten years,Irrelevant

Most large wineries age their wine in large temperaturecontrolled stainless steel tanks that are above ground while smaller wineries may still store their wine in wooden barrels in damp wine cellars,Irrelevant
The wine is then filtered one last time to remove unwanted sediment,Relevant
The wine is now ready to be bottled corked sealed crated labeled and shipped to distributors,Irrelevant
Most medium to largesized wineries I now use automated bottling machines and most moderately priced and expensive wine bottles have corks made of a special oak,Irrelevant
The corks are covered with a peeloff aluminum foil or plastic seal,Relevant
Cheaper wines have an aluminum screwoff cap or plastic stopper,Irrelevant
The corks and screw caps keep the air from spoiling the wine,Irrelevant
Wine is usually shipped in wooden crates though cheaper wines may be packaged in cardboard,Irrelevant
The major steps necessary to process wool from the sheep to the fabric are shearing cleaning and scouring grading and sorting carding spinning weaving and finishing,Irrelevant
Sheep are sheared once a year—usually in the springtime,Relevant
A veteran shearer can shear up to two hundred sheep per day,Irrelevant
The fleece recovered from a sheep can weigh between 6 and 18 pounds (27 and 81 kilograms) as much as possible the fleece is kept in one piece,Irrelevant
While most sheep are still sheared by hand new technologies have been developed that use computers and sensitive robotcontrolled arms to do the clipping,Irrelevant
Grading is the breaking up of the fleece based on overall quality,Irrelevant
In sorting the wool is broken up into sections of different quality fibers from different parts of the body,Relevant
The best quality of wool comes from the shoulders and sides of the sheep and is used for clothing the lesser quality comes from the lower legs and is used to make rugs,Irrelevant
In wool grading high quality does not always mean high durability,Irrelevant
Wool taken directly from the sheep is called raw or grease wool,Irrelevant
It contains sand dirt grease and dried sweat (called suint) the weight of contaminants accounts for about 30 to 70 percent of the After being carded the wool fibers are spun into yarn,Irrelevant
Spinning for woolen yarns is typically done on a mule spinning machine while worsted yarns can be spun on any number of spinning machines,Irrelevant
After the yarn is spun it is wrapped around bobbins cones or commercial drums,Relevant
After being carded the wool fibers are spun into yarn,Relevant
Spinning for woolen yarns is typically done on a mule spinning machine while worsted yarns can be spun on any number of spinning machines,Irrelevant
After the yarn is spun it is wrapped around bobbins cones or commercial drums fleeces total weight,Relevant
To remove these contaminants the wool is scoured in a series of alkaline baths containing water soap and soda ash or a similar alkali,Relevant
The byproducts from this process (such as lanolin) are saved and used in a variety of household products,Relevant
Rollers in the scouring machines squeeze excess water from the fleece but the fleece is not allowed to dry completely,Relevant
Following this process the wool is often treated with oil to give it increased manageability,Relevant
Next the fibers are passed through a series of metal teeth that straighten and blend them into slivers,Relevant
Carding also removes residual dirt and other matter left in the fibers,Relevant
Carded wool intended for worsted yarn is put through gilling and combing two procedures that remove short fibers and place the longer fibers parallel to each other,Relevant
From there the sleeker slivers are compacted and thinned through a process called drawing,Relevant
Carded wool to be used for woolen yarn is sent directly for spinning,Relevant
Thread is formed by spinning the fibers together to form one strand of yarn the strand is spun with two three or four other strands,Irrelevant
Since the fibers cling and stick to one another it is fairly easy to join extend and spin wool into yarn,Irrelevant
Spinning for woolen yarns is typically done on a mule spinning machine while worsted yarns can be spun on any number of spinning machines,Irrelevant
After the yarn is spun it is wrapped around bobbins cones or commercial drums,Relevant
Next the wool yarn is woven into fabric,Relevant
Wool manufacturers use two basic weaves the plain weave and the twill,Irrelevant
Woolen yarns are made into fabric using a plain weave (rarely a twill) which produces a fabric of a somewhat looser weave and a soft surface (due to napping) with little or no luster,Relevant
The napping often conceals flaws in construction,Relevant
Worsted yarns can create fine fabrics with exquisite patterns using a twill weave,Irrelevant
The result is a more tightly woven smooth fabric,Irrelevant
Better constructed worsteds are more durable than woolens and therefore more costly,Irrelevant

After weaving both worsteds and woolens undergo a series of finishing procedures including fulling (immersing the fabric in water to make the fibers interlock) crabbing (permanently setting the interlock) decating (shrinkproofing) and occasionally dyeing,Relevant
Although wool fibers can be dyed before the carding process dyeing can also be done after the wool has been woven into fabric,Relevant
Todays zippers comprise key components of either metal or plastic,Irrelevant
Beyond this one very important difference the steps involved in producing the finished product are essentially the same,Irrelevant
A stringer consists of the tape (or cloth) and teeth that make up one side of the zipper,Irrelevant
The oldest process for making the stringers for a metal zipper is that process invented by Otto Sundback in 1923,Irrelevant
A round wire is sent through a rolling mill shaping it into a Yshape,Relevant
This wire is then sliced to form a tooth whose width is appropriate for the type of zipper desired,Relevant
The tooth is then put into a slot on a rotating turntable to be punched into the shape of a scoop by a die,Relevant
The turntable is rotated 90 degrees and another tooth is fed into the slot,Relevant
After another 90 degrees turn the first tooth is clamped onto the cloth tape,Relevant
The tape must be raised slightly over twice the thickness of the scoop—the cupped tooth—after clamping to allow room for the opposite tooth on the completed zipper,Relevant
A slow and tedious process its popularity has waned,Irrelevant
To make the stringer for a spiral plastic zipper a round plastic wire is notched and then fed between two heated screws,Irrelevant
These screws one rotating clockwise the other counterclockwise pull the plastic wire out to form loops,Irrelevant
A head maker at the front of each loop then forms it into a round knob,Irrelevant
This method requires that a left spiral and right spiral be made simultaneously on two separate machines so that the chains will match up on a finished zipper,Irrelevant
Another similar method originated in the 1940s,Irrelevant
This entails a flattened strip of wire passing between a heading punch and a pocket punch to form scoops,Relevant
A blanking punch cuts around the scoops to form a Y shape,Relevant
The legs of the Y are then clamped around the cloth tape,Relevant
This method proved to be faster and more effective than Sundback s original,Irrelevant
Yet another method developed in the 1930s uses molten metal to form teeth,Irrelevant
A mold shaped like a chain of teeth is clamped around the cloth tape,Irrelevant
Molten zinc under pressure is then injected into the mold,Relevant
Water cools the mold which then releases the shaped teeth,Relevant
Any residue is trimmed,Relevant
Plastic zippers can be spiral toothed ladder or woven directly into the fabric,Irrelevant
Two methods are used to make the stringers for a spiral plastic zipper,Irrelevant
The first involves notching a round plastic wire before feeding it between two heated screws,Relevant
These screws one rotating clockwise the other counterclockwise pull the plastic wire out to form loops,Relevant
A head maker at the front of each loop then forms it into a round knob,Relevant
Next the plastic spiral is cooled with air,Relevant
This method requires that a left spiral and right spiral be made simultaneously on two separate machines so that the chains will match up on a finished zipper,Irrelevant
The second method for spiral plastic zippers makes both the left and right spiral simultaneously on one machine,Irrelevant
A piece of wire is looped twice between notches on a rotating forming wheel,Relevant
A pusher and head maker simultaneously press the plastic wires firmly into the notches and form the heads,Relevant
This process makes two chains that are already linked together to be sewn onto two cloth tapes,Relevant
To make the stringers for a toothed plastic zipper a molding process is used that is similar to the metal process described in step #2 above,Relevant
A rotating wheel has on its edge several small molds that are shaped like flattened teeth,Relevant
Two cords run through the molds to connect the finished teeth together,Relevant
Semimolten plastic is fed into the mold where it is held until it solidifies,Relevant
A folding machine bends the teeth into a Ushape that can be sewn onto a cloth tape,Relevant
The stringers for a ladder plastic zipper are made by winding a plastic wire onto alternating spools that protrude from the edge of a rotating forming wheel,Irrelevant

Strippers on each side lift the loops off the spools while a heading and notching wheel simultaneously presses the loops into a U shape and forms heads on the teeth which are then sewn onto the cloth tape,Irrelevant
Superior garment zippers can be made by weaving the plastic wire directly into the cloth using the same method as is used in cloth weaving,Irrelevant
This method is not common in the United States but such zippers are frequently imported,Irrelevant
Once the individual stringers have been made they are first joined together with a temporary device similar to a slider,Relevant
They are then pressed and in the case of metal zippers wire brushes scrub down sharp edges,Relevant
The tapes are then starched wrung out and dried,Relevant
Metal zippers are then waxed for smooth operation and both types are rolled onto huge spools to be formed later into complete zippers,Relevant
The slider and pull tab are assembled separately after being stamped or diecast from metal,Relevant
The continuous zipper tape is then unrolled from its spool and its teeth are removed at intervals leaving spaces that surround smaller chains,Relevant
For zippers that only open on one end the bottom stop is first clamped on and then the slider is threaded onto the chain,Relevant
Next the top stops are clamped on and the gaps between lengths of teeth are cut at midpoint,Relevant
For zippers that separate the midpoint of each gap is coated with reinforcing tape and the top stops are clamped on,Relevant
The tape is then sliced to separate the strips of chain again,Relevant
The slider and the box are then slipped onto one chain and the pin is slipped onto the other,Relevant

The basic elements of a zipper are the stringer (the tape and teeth assembly that makes up one side of a zipper) the slider (opens and closes the zipper) a tab (pulled to move the slider) and stops (prevent the slider from leaving the chain),Irrelevant
Finished zippers are stacked placed in boxes and trucked to clothing manufacturers luggage manufacturers or any of the other manufacturers that rely on zippers,Relevant
Some are also shipped to department stores or fabric shops for direct purchase by the consumer,Relevant

The sand and gravel that contain zircon mixed with silicate ilmenite and rutile are typically collected from coastal waters by a floating dredge a large steam shovel fitted on a floating barge,Relevant
After the shovel has scooped up the gravel and sand they are purified by means of spiral concentrators which separate on the basis of density,Relevant
The ilmenite and rutile are then removed by magnetic and electrostatic separators,Relevant
The purest concentrates of zircon are shipped to endproduct manufacturers to be used in metal production while less pure concentrations are used for refractories,Relevant

Endproduct manufacturers of zircon further refine the nearly pure zircon into zirconium by using a reducing agent (usually chlorine) to purify the metal and then sintering (heating) it until it becomes sufficiently ductile—workable—for industrial use,Relevant
For smallscale laboratory use zirconium metal may be produced by means of a chemical reaction in which chloride is used to reduce the zircon,Relevant
The lesspure zircon is made into zirconia an oxide of zirconium by fusing the zircon with coke iron borings and lime until the silica is reduced to silicon that alloys with the iron,Relevant
The zirconia is then stabilized by heating it to about 3095 degrees Fahrenheit (1700 degrees Celsius) with additions of lime and magnesia totalling about five percent,Relevant
As mentioned above baddeleyite contains relatively high pure concentrations of zirconium oxide that can be used without filtering or cleansing,Irrelevant
The only refining process used on baddeleyite involves grinding the gravel or sand to a powder and sizing the powder with different sized sieves,Relevant
All zirconium oxide that comes from baddeleyite is used for refractories and increasingly advanced ceramics,Relevant
The mold for producing sheets is assembled from two plates of polished glass separated by a flexible windowframe spacer,Relevant
The spacer sits along the outer perimeter of the surface of the glass plates and forms a sealed cavity between the plates,Relevant

The fact that the spacer is flexible allows the mold cavity to shrink during the polymerization process to compensate for the volume contraction of the material as the reaction goes from individual molecules to linked polymers,Irrelevant
In some production applications polished metal plates are used instead of glass,Irrelevant
Several plates may be stacked on top of each other with the upper surface of one plate becoming the bottom surface of the next higher mold cavity,Relevant
The plates and spacers are clamped together with spring clamps,Relevant
An open comer of each mold cavity is filled with a premeasured liquid syrup of methyl methacrylate monomer and catalyst,Relevant
In some cases a methyl methacrylate prepolymer is also added,Irrelevant
A prepolymer is a material with partially formed polymer chains used to further help the polymerization process,Irrelevant
The liquid syrup flows throughout the mold cavity to fill it,Relevant
The mold is then sealed and heat may be applied to help the catalyst start the reaction,Irrelevant
As the reaction proceeds it may generate significant heat by itself,Irrelevant
This heat is fanned off in air ovens or by placing the molds in a water bath,Relevant
A programmed temperature cycle is followed to ensure proper cure time without additional vaporization of the monomer solution,Relevant
This also prevents bubbles from forming,Irrelevant
Thinner sheets may cure in 10 to 12 hours but thicker sheets may require several days,Irrelevant
When the plastic is cured the molds are cooled and opened,Relevant
The glass or metal plates are cleaned and reassembled for the next batch,Relevant

The plastic sheets are either used as is or are annealed by heating them to 284302°F (140150°C) for several hours to reduce any residual stresses in the material that might cause warping or other dimensional instabilities,Relevant
Any excess material or flash is trimmed off the edges and masking paper or plastic film is applied to the surface of the finished sheets for protection during handling and shipping,Relevant
The paper or film is often marked with the materials brand name size and handling instructions,Relevant
Conformance with applicable safety or building code standards is also noted,Relevant
The continuous process is similar to the batch cell process but because the sheets are thinner and smaller the process times are much shorter,Irrelevant
The syrup of monomer and catalyst is introduced at one end of a set of horizontal stainless steel belts running parallel one above the other,Relevant
The distance between the belts determines the thickness of the sheet to be formed,Irrelevant
The belts hold the reacting monomer and catalyst syrup between them and move it through a series of heating and cooling zones according to a programmed temperature cycle to cure the material,Relevant
Electric heaters or hot air may then anneal the material as it comes out of the end of the belts,Irrelevant
The sheets are cut to size and masking paper or plastic film is applied,Relevant
The modern method for making aluminum beverage cans is called twopiece drawing and wall ironing,Irrelevant
The process begins with an aluminum ingot which was cast to be about 30 inches (76 cm) thick then rolled into a thin sheet,Relevant
The first step in the actual manufacture of the can is to cut the sheet into a circle called a blank that will form the bottom and sides of the can,Relevant
Each blank is 55 inches (14 cm) in diameter,Irrelevant

Some material is necessarily lost between each circle but manufacturers have found that minimum aluminum is lost when the sheets are wide enough to hold two staggered rows of seven blanks each,Irrelevant
About 1214 of the sheet is wasted but can be reused as scrap,Irrelevant
After the circular blank is cut it is drawn or pulled up to form a cup 35 inches (89 cm) in diameter,Relevant
The small ripples at the top of the metal are called ears,Irrelevant
Earing is an unavoidable effect of the crystalline structure of the aluminum sheet,Irrelevant
The small cup resulting from the initial draw is then transferred to a second machine,Relevant
A sleeve holds the cup precisely in place and a punch lowered swiftly into the cup redraws it to a diameter of about 26 inches (66 cm),Relevant
The height of the cup increases simultaneously from the initial 13 to 225 inches (33 to 57 cm),Irrelevant
The punch then pushes the cup against three rings called ironing rings which stretch and thin the cup walls,Relevant
This entire operation—the drawing and ironing—is done in one continuous punch stroke which takes only one fifth of a second to complete,Irrelevant
The cup is now about 5 inches (13 cm) high,Irrelevant
Then another punch presses up against the base of the cup causing the bottom to bulge inward,Irrelevant
This shape counteracts the pressure of the carbonated liquid the can will contain,Relevant
The bottom and lower walls of the can are also a little thicker than the upper walls for added strength,Irrelevant
The drawing and ironing process leaves the can slightly wavy at the top,Irrelevant
These small ripples in the metal are called ears,Irrelevant
Earing is an unavoidable effect of the crystalline structure of the aluminum sheet,Irrelevant
Aluminum companies have studied this phenomenon extensively and they have been able to influence the placement and height of the ears by controlling the rolling of the aluminum sheet,Irrelevant
Nevertheless some material is lost at this stage,Irrelevant
About a quarter inch is trimmed from the top of the can leaving the upper walls straight and level,Irrelevant
The drawing and ironing process leaves the outer wall of the can with a smooth shiny surface so it does not require any further finishing such as polishing,Irrelevant
After the ears are trimmed the can is cleaned and then imprinted with its label,Relevant
After the can is decorated it is squeezed in slightly at the top to a make a neck and the neck is given an outward flange at the very top edge which will be folded over once the lid is added,Relevant
The lid is made of a slightly different alloy than the aluminum for the base and sides of the can,Irrelevant

The inward bulge of the bottom of the can helps it withstand the pressure exerted by the liquid inside it but the flat lid must be stiffer and stronger than the base so it is made of aluminum with more magnesium and less manganese than the rest of the can,Irrelevant
This results in stronger metal and the lid is considerably thicker than the walls,Irrelevant
The lid is cut to a diameter of 21 inches (53 cm) smaller than the 26inch (66 cm) diameter of the walls,Relevant
The center of the lid is stretched upward slightly and drawn by a machine to form a rivet,Relevant
The pull tab a separate piece of metal is inserted under the rivet and secured by it,Relevant
Then the lid is scored so that when the tab is pulled by the consumer the metal will detach easily and leave the proper opening,Relevant
To ensure that the cans are made properly they are automatically checked for cracks and pinholes,Relevant
One in 50000 cans is usually found to be defective,Irrelevant
After the neck is formed the can is ready to be filled,Relevant
The can is held tightly against the seat of a filling machine and a beverage is poured in,Relevant
The lid is added,Relevant
The upper flange formed when the can was given its neck is then bent around the lid and seamed shut,Relevant
At this point the can is ready for sale,Relevant
The assembly process for the cartridge components begins with a thorough cleaning and polishing of the case by a vibratory finisher,Relevant
The finisher works by vibrating a corn byproduct (dried and ground corncobs) with a polishing compound around the cases creating a high luster,Relevant
Thus prepared they are ready for final assembly,Irrelevant
This is how a typical centerfire metal cartridge is assembled 1 The cases are fed into a loading press which first sizes the case,Relevant
This sizing Ammunitionforms the metal case to standard dimensions,Irrelevant
The case must be within 0001 inch for it to function correctly,Irrelevant
The primer is then pressed into the case primer hole flush with the base,Relevant
The primer must be flush or the cartridge will not feed properly in the weapon magazine causing a jam,Irrelevant
At the same time the mouth of the case is slightly expanded in preparation for receiving the bullet 3 The case is charged or filled with the correct amount of propellant,Irrelevant
This step is of utmost importance for miscalculation or double charging could be disastrous,Irrelevant
The bullet is firmly seated into the open end of the case,Relevant
The bullet has a coating of lubricant to prevent corrosion and assist in the assembly process,Relevant
The bullet is then crimped into the case to give the correct overall length of the cartridge,Relevant
The crimp reduces the diameter of the open end of the case and captures the bullet tightly sealing the assembly together so moisture cannot invade the powder,Irrelevant
The press used to assemble cartridges must feed each component accurately and in the correct sequence,Irrelevant
Otherwise cases could be unprimed powder left out or bullets seated incorrectly,Irrelevant
Any of these could result in a misfire or loss of accuracy at the minimum and at worst cause the firearm to blow apart upon firing,Irrelevant
In each stage of the process special dies perform the important assembly function,Relevant
The dies are made of tooling carbide for long life and have close adjustments to produce quality ammunition,Irrelevant
After assembly the finished cartridges are packaged usually 50 to a box and prepared for shipment to the shooter,Relevant
The manufacturing process for antilock brake systems consists of manufacturing the component parts and then installing those parts on the vehicle,Irrelevant
The parts are built in one plant then packaged and shipped to a vehicle assembly plant for installation,Irrelevant
This is a typical process for an automobile antilock brake system,Irrelevant
The master cylinder including the base for the solenoid body is cast as a single unit,Irrelevant
The seating and sealing surfaces are machined smooth and the connection ports are threaded,Irrelevant
The individual primary and secondary pistons solenoid coils reservoir caps and seals pressure accumulator and any metering and proportioning valves are installed,Irrelevant
The solenoid body has a cover which attaches to the master cylinder with four or more screws and is sealed with a gasket,Irrelevant
The toothed wheel is cast from iron,Irrelevant
Minor machining may be required at the mounting points,Irrelevant
The pickup coils are wound around the permanent magnet core in a machine called a coil winder,Irrelevant
The entire assembly is encased or potted in plastic resin with an electrical connector attached,Irrelevant
The electronic controller components are soldered to a printed circuit board,Irrelevant
The board is connected inside a protective housing and mounted to the cast aluminum heat sink base,Irrelevant
Extemal electrical connections are provided for the input wiring from each speed sensor and the output wiring to the solenoids in the master brake cylinder,Irrelevant
In the automobile assembly plant the steel tubing brake lines are installed in the framework of the body,Irrelevant
They run from the partition between the engine compartment and the occupant compartment called the firewall to the vicinity of each wheel,Irrelevant
The electrical wires for the ABS are also run from the vicinity of each wheel to the controller location and from the controller to the firewall,Irrelevant
The brake master cylinder is bolted to the firewall in the engine compartment near the brake pedal,Relevant
The brake lines are attached to the appropriate ports on the solenoid body and the electrical wires are connected,Relevant
The toothed sensor wheels are pressed onto the outer constant velocity joints or the ends of the axle spindles so that they ride just inside the wheels,Relevant
Once the axles are attached to the frame the brake lines are attached and the pickup coils are installed so that the end of the coils are close to the toothed wheels,Relevant
The pickup coils are then electrically connected to the wires to the controller,Irrelevant
The controller is installed either under the instrument panel or in the vehicles trunk,Relevant
The electrical connections are made including the power connection from the vehicle battery through the fusebox,Relevant
The refining process starts by piping the crude petroleum from a storage tank into a heat exchanger or tube heater where its temperature is rapidly raised for initial distillation,Relevant
It then enters an atmospheric distillation tower where the lighter and more volatile components or fractions vaporize and are drawn off through a series of condensers and coolers,Relevant

It is then separated for further refining into gasoline (considered a light distillate) kerosene (considered a medium distillate) diesel oil (considered a heavy distillate) and many other useful petroleum products,Relevant
The heavy residue from this atmospheric distillation process is commonly called topped crude,Irrelevant
This topped crude may be used for fuel oil or further processed into other products such as asphalt,Irrelevant
Vacuum distillation may remove enough high boiling fractions to yield what is called a straight run asphalt,Irrelevant

However if the topped crude contains enough low volatile components which cannot be economically removed through distillation solvent extraction—also known as solvent deasphalting—may be required to produce asphalt cement of the desired consistency,Irrelevant
Asphalt may next be blended or cut back with a volatile substance resulting in a product that is soft and workable at a lower temperature than pure asphalt cement,Relevant
When the cutback asphalt is used for paving or construction the volatile element evaporates when exposed to air or heat leaving the hard asphalt cement,Relevant
The relative speed of evaporation or volatility of the cutting agent determines whether a cutback asphalt is classified as slow medium or rapidcuring,Relevant

Heated asphalt cement is mixed with residual asphaltic oil from the earlier distillation process for a slowcuring asphalt with kerosene for mediumcuring and with gasoline or naphtha for the rapidcuring asphalt,Relevant
The asphalt cement may also be emulsified to produce a liquid that can be easily pumped through pipes mixed with aggregate or sprayed through nozzles,Relevant
To emulsify the asphalt cement is ground into globules 5 to 10 microns and smaller (one micron is equal to one millionth of a meter),Relevant
This is mixed with water,Relevant
An emulsifying agent is added which reduces the tendency of the asphalt and water to separate,Relevant
The emulsifying agent may be colloidal clay soluble or insoluble silicates soap or sulphonated vegetable oils,Relevant
Asphalt may also be pulverized to produce a powdered asphalt,Relevant
The asphalt is crushed and passed through a series of fine mesh sieves to ensure uniform size of the granules,Relevant
Powered asphalt can be mixed with road oil and aggregate for pavement construction,Relevant

The heat and pressure in the road slowly amalgamates the powder with the aggregate and binding oil and the Asphalt Cementsubstance hardens to a consistency similar to regular asphalt cement,Irrelevant
If the asphalt is to be used for a purpose other than paving such as roofing pipe coating or as an undersealant or waterproofing material the asphalt may be oxidized or air blown,Irrelevant
This process produces a material that softens at a higher temperature than paving asphalts,Irrelevant
It may be air blown at the refinery at an asphalt processing plant or at a roofing material plant,Irrelevant
The asphalt is heated to 500°F (260°C),Relevant
Then air is bubbled through it for one to 45 hours,Relevant
When cooled the asphalt remains liquid,Relevant
Prior to its use the latex may need to be colored,Irrelevant
This involves mixing a pigment into the latex,Relevant
It may be done at the balloon factory or the balloon maker may purchase alreadypigmented latex from a supplier,Irrelevant
The latex must be poured into tanks into which the forms will be dipped,Relevant
The tanks are kept at a certain temperature and may include stirring mechanisms to keep the latex circulating to avoid settling,Irrelevant
The balloon forms are first heated then immersed in a tank of coagulant solution for a few seconds,Relevant
When the forms are immersed in the liquid latex the coagulant will cause the rubber to gel in a thin sheet around the forms,Irrelevant
A commonly used coagulant solution is a mixture of water a calciumbased salt soap and talc powder,Relevant
The salt is the actual coagulant the soap helps the latex spread in an even film and the talc helps ease the removal of the rubber from the forms in a later step,Irrelevant
The forms are heated to a temperature between 100°F (38°C) and 200°F (93°C) and then immersed in a tank of colored latex,Relevant
The coagulant causes the latex to coat the forms,Relevant
The longer the forms are left in the tank the thicker the coating that sticks to them,Relevant
For balloons a very thin layer of latex is desired so the forms are immersed only for a few seconds,Irrelevant
The forms must be inserted and removed at carefully controlled speeds to avoid trapping air bubbles and to achieve an even thin coating,Irrelevant
A lip is formed on the neck of the balloon by rolling the edges of the rubber using brushes or rollers,Relevant
This creates the ring seen around the opening of the balloon,Relevant
Next the forms are immersed in a tank of leaching solution (often plain water) to dissolve and leach away excess coagulant from the rubber,Relevant
The rubber on the forms must be dried and cured,Relevant
The method used varies among manufacturers,Irrelevant
Some balloon makers use a latex that already contains a vulcanizing agent in which case the rubber is dried at a moderate temperature,Irrelevant
Other makers induce vulcanization by putting the rubbercoated forms into an oven and curing for as long as an hour,Irrelevant
The balloons are then mechanically removed from their forms,Relevant
One approach is to blow them off using a spray of water or air and collecting the balloons in a basket or net,Irrelevant
If the balloons are removed using a spray of water they are next placed in a centrifuge where excess water is removed by spinning the balloons around at high speed,Irrelevant
The balloons are then dried in large tumble dryers,Relevant
Next the balloons may either be packaged or first printed and then packaged,Relevant
If they are packaged directly they are moved on a conveyor belt past a counting device and placed into bags,Relevant
When an appropriate number of balloons has been placed in each bag the bags are sealed,Relevant
Printing designs on balloons such as logos or faces actually involves several steps,Irrelevant
First the balloons must be inflated in order to allow even printing,Relevant
This requires a worker to manually place each balloon on the inflating device,Relevant
Next a pattern is carefully printed on each balloon,Relevant
Finally the balloons are removed and passed on to the packaging stage,Relevant
Iron ore coke and limestone are heated in a blast furnace by hot pressurized air,Relevant
The coke produces heat (to melt the iron ore) and carbon monoxide (which reacts with iron oxides in the ore to release iron),Irrelevant
The limestone reacts with impurities in the iron ore such as sulfur to form slag which is removed,Irrelevant
The final product of the blast furnace is pig iron which contains at least 90 iron 35 carbon and various impurities,Irrelevant
To convert pig iron into steel the impurities and most of the carbon must be removed,Irrelevant
(Iron without carbon is much weaker than steel but iron with too much carbon is brittle),Irrelevant
Various methods exist to purify pig iron the most common of which is the basic oxygen steel (BOS) process,Irrelevant
In this method oxygen is blasted into molten pig iron under high pressure,Relevant
Carbon is released as carbon monoxide and the impurities are released as slag,Relevant
The remaining molten steel is poured into molds and allowed to cool into ingots weighing thousands of pounds each,Relevant
A billet is a bar of steel with a square crosssection whose dimensions are usually less than about 6 inches (15 cm) by 6 inches (15 cm),Relevant
(If the dimensions are larger the bar is known as a bloom if the crosssection is rectangular rather than square the bar is known as a slab),Irrelevant
A steel ingot is heated until it is about 2192°F (1200°C) then rolled back and forth between grooved rolls until it has reached the proper size,Relevant
Giant shears cut the billet to the desired length then it is allowed to cool,Relevant
It is also possible to form billets directly from molten steel by pouring it through a watercooled copper mold to shape it then spraying it with water to solidify it,Irrelevant
To make barbed wire iron ore coke and limestone are heated in a blast furnace to produce pig iron,Irrelevant
The pig iron is purified and converted to steel,Relevant
The steel billet is again heated and rolled until it has been shaped into a round bar 02 inch (56 mm) in diameter known as a wire rod,Relevant
The wire rod is rolled into a coil weighing as much as 3969 pounds (1800 kg) which is shipped to the wire manufacturer,Relevant
Scale a surface coating of iron oxide which forms on steel when it is heated must be removed from the wire rod,Irrelevant
This can be done by soaking it in hot dilute acid (sulfuric acid at 180°F [82°C] or hydrochloric acid at 140°F [60°C]) and rinsing it with water a process known as pickling,Irrelevant

Scale can also be removed by bending the wire rod back and forth between a series of wheels to break it off or by blasting it off with fastmoving particles of sand aluminum oxide or castiron shot,Relevant
The clean wire rod is coated with lime borax or phosphate,Relevant
This coating prevents rusting neutralizes any remaining traces of acid and helps lubricants adhere to the wire rod when it is made into wire,Irrelevant
One end of the coated wire rod is shaped to a point,Irrelevant
This end is inserted like a thread going through the eye of a needle into a die consisting of a very hard central nib made of tungsten carbide surrounded by a steel holder,Irrelevant
The wire rod is lubricated with oil or soap and is pulled through the die to reduce its diameter,Relevant
This process is known as drawing,Irrelevant
A series of dies are used to reduce the wire rod from its Barbed Wireoriginal size to the desired size of the wire,Irrelevant
For barbed wire the diameter is typically 0097 inch (25 mm),Irrelevant
Usually about six or seven dies are needed to reach this size,Irrelevant
Drawing the wire causes it to become hard and stiff,Irrelevant
To make it pliable it is heated a process known as annealing,Irrelevant
Wire can be annealed by heating it in a bath of molten salt a bath of molten lead or in a furnace containing nitrogen,Irrelevant
All these methods prevent scale from forming by protecting the steel from oxygen,Irrelevant
Wire to be made into barbed wire is usually galvanized (coated with zinc) to protect it from corrosion,Irrelevant
The wire must be perfectly clean and dry to be properly galvanized,Irrelevant
First it is cleaned in a bath of hot dilute hydrochloric acid then rinsed with hot water,Relevant
It then passes through a solution of hot zinc chloride or ammonium chloride to prevent rust from forming as it is dried,Relevant
After drying the wire passes through a bath of molten zinc,Relevant
Excess zinc is wiped off and the coated wire is allowed to cool,Relevant
(Sometimes the wire is coated with aluminum instead in a similar way),Irrelevant
Wire can also be coated with zinc by a process known as electrogalvanizing,Irrelevant
The wire is given a negative electric charge and passed through a solution of zinc sulfate or some other zinc salt,Relevant
The positive zinc ions are attracted to the negative wire and form a coating,Relevant
A single automated machine performs all the steps needed to transform galvanized wire into barbed wire,Relevant
Two wires are fed into the machine and twisted together to form the cable,Relevant
Another wire is fed into the machine from the side and twisted around one or both of the cable wires,Relevant
This wire is cut at an angle on both sides to form a twopoint barb,Relevant
Two wires are twisted and cut together if fourpoint barbs are needed,Relevant
The barbed wire is pulled along a set distance (usually 4 or 5 inches [10 or 13 cm]) and the process is repeated to space the barbs evenly,Relevant
The barbed wire is wound onto spools and cut into 1319foot (402 m) lengths,Relevant
These spools are then loaded onto trucks and shipped to the customer,Relevant
A mill worker places each split onto an automatic lathe that shaves the rough edges off as it turns the wood,Irrelevant
The billets as they are now called are inspected again for straightness of grain,Irrelevant
The billets are stacked and strapped together into sixsided bundles,Relevant
Workers paint the ends with a protective preservative to keep the wood from fraying or rotting,Relevant
The bundled billets are then trucked to the lumberyard of the bat manufacturer,Relevant
The billets that arrive at the lumberyard are considered green wood because they still contain sap and gum,Relevant
In order to strengthen the wood the sap and gum must be removed by an airdrying process called seasoning,Irrelevant
To achieve the proper seasoning the billets are simply stacked in the yard for a period of six months to two years,Relevant
The plant workers who create the final product are called bat turners,Irrelevant
They are highly skilled artisans who have been specially trained for the intricate work,Irrelevant
When an order is placed the bat turner selects a billet from the storage bin and creates a replica of the desired model,Relevant
When the billets have dried completely they are weighed and inspected for quality,Relevant
A worker places each billet on an automatic lathe and shapes it into a rough baseball bat shape with a narrowed neck,Irrelevant
The bat forms are sanded inspected once more and then sorted according to weight,Relevant
The bat manufacturer keeps a model of each bat made typically identified by the baseball player who initially ordered it,Irrelevant
When a player or team places an order the order may look like this six Johnny Bench models ten Hank Aarons four Mickey Mantles,Irrelevant
The plant workers who create the final product are called bat turners,Irrelevant
They are highly skilled artisans who have been specially trained for the intricate work,Irrelevant
When an order is placed the bat turner selects a billet from the storage bin that fits the calledfor weight and length,Relevant
The billet is placed on a lathe,Relevant
The model bat is placed on a rack above and behind the lathe,Relevant
The bat turner revolves the billet slowly on the lathe sanding and shaving it to an exact replica of the model,Relevant
Using calipers the bat turner measures the billet every 12 inches (2545 cm) and weighs it repeatedly until it is perfect,Relevant
The bat is branded with the company trademark and the signature of the player associated with the model,Relevant
The trademark is placed onequarter of a turn from the sweet spot (the ideal spot where the ball should strike the bat),Relevant
If the order calls for staining the bat is dipped into a staining vat,Irrelevant
All of the bats are then varnished packed into cartons and shipped to the player or team,Relevant
The metal is either cast into molds (gray cast iron) or drawn into sheet and formed (steel),Relevant
Before enameling it must then be cleaned,Relevant
Cleaning of castings is carried out by blasting the surface with chilled iron grit sometimes after preliminary annealing (heating at 13501500°F [730820°C]),Relevant
The grit or shot is projected through nozzles using compressed air or flung against the surface by centrifugal force using a special machine,Irrelevant
A combination of both methods may be used,Irrelevant
This blasting removes any dirt or sand particles from the mold from the metal surface,Irrelevant
Sheet metal must undergo a more complex cleaning process,Irrelevant
First the surface is cleaned by shotblasting after annealing to release stresses and to remove any grease deposits,Relevant
Degreasing is done with chemical cleaners first with an organic solvent followed by a hot alkaline solution,Relevant
The organic solvent removes most of the grease and oil from the metal surface,Relevant
The alkaline solution removes the remaining film of oil and leaves a surface ready for acid pickling,Relevant
Acid pickling uses hydrochloric or sulfuric acid or a combination of these acids,Relevant
This process descales the surface which helps to form a strong bond between the iron and groundcoat enamel,Irrelevant
Pickling is followed by rinsing in running water,Relevant
The next step is sometimes a nickel dip which uses a solution of nickel sulfate and boric acid to coat the metal with a layer of nickel,Relevant
This layer also helps to form a good bond with the enamel,Relevant
The nickel dip is followed by a thorough rinsing of the ware and another dip in a neutralizer solution,Relevant
This solution consists of soda ash and borax in water and removes any traces of acid as well as prevents rust,Irrelevant
After neutralizing the metal is dried as quickly as possible to prevent rusting,Relevant

After the raw materials are carefully weighed and mixed together in precise amounts the enamel frit is prepared by melting the batch in furnaces of rotary or continuous type fueled by oil or gas,Relevant
When melting is completed the molten enamel is run out of the furnace in a thin stream into a tank of cold water which produces small fragments,Relevant
For continuous furnaces the molten frit is run between watercooled rolls which chills the frit,Relevant
The frit is then dried and stored in bags,Relevant
Before the enamel is applied it must be ground into a powder using a ball mill with blocks of enamel as the grinding media,Relevant
If applied wet the enamel is milled with additions of clay and water to make a slip or slurry,Irrelevant
Dry enamel is dusted on the metal surface which has been previously heated to a temperature above the melting point of the enamel,Relevant
The powder melts on contact with the hot article forming a continuous coating,Relevant
Firing in a furnace produces a smooth porcelainlike surface,Relevant
Wet enamel is applied by a dipping process using a large open tank,Relevant
After dipping the coated part is allowed to drain producing a thin uniform coating,Relevant
The dipping tank uses a recalculating system to recycle the enamel,Irrelevant
The wet enamel may also be applied using automatic spraying equipment,Relevant
After enameling the coated parts are dried using cabinet or conveyor dryers heated by gas burners steam or wasteheat from the enameling furnaces or infrared lamps,Relevant
Firing takes place in furnaces heated by metallic heating elements,Irrelevant
Two coatings of enamel are normally applied a ground coat followed by a cover coat,Relevant
The cover coat takes longer to fire,Relevant

A number of processes are used to form plastics into shapes including calendaring (squeezing between rollers to form films) casting compression molding and injection molding (melting and forcing into a cooled mold),Irrelevant

In injection molding a reciprocating screw machine is generally used which melts the plastic pressurizes the melt to inject it into a closed mold closes the mold so the plastic can solidify and opens the mold to allow removal of the part,Relevant
Injection occurs as the screw is hydraulically forced forward in the barrel,Relevant
During the cooling and solidification period the screw begins to rotate and melt new material for the next part,Relevant
Compression molding is used to make both plastic and fiber reinforced bathtubs,Relevant
For reinforced bathtubs a mixture of fibers polyester resin and pigments fillers and other additives are mixed together and formed into a sheet,Relevant
In this process a specified amount of resin filler paste is placed onto a plastic carrier film using a special machine,Relevant
The carrier film is passed under a chopper which cuts glass roving into short lengths,Relevant
After the glass falls to the resin bed another carrier film with another layer of paste is added on top sandwiching the glass between the two layers,Relevant
This sandwich structure is passed through a series of compaction rollers to thoroughly mix the fibers and resin,Relevant

After the material—called a sheet molding compound—thickens the carrier film is removed and the sheet material is cut into charges which are placed in matched metal die molds made of machined steel,Relevant
High pressure is applied which heats the material so that it flows to all areas of the mold,Relevant
Heat from the mold activates the catalyst which achieves curing,Relevant
Once cured the part is then removed from the mold,Relevant
Two processes called hand layup and spray layup are used to make fiberglass bathtubs,Irrelevant
Hand layup is a method in which successive plies of reinforcing material or resinimpregnated reinforcement are positioned in a mold by hand,Irrelevant
Cure occurs at room temperature with no applied pressure,Irrelevant
Special tools are used to work out air bubbles and ensure complete wetting of the fiber if the polymer is added separately,Irrelevant
The spray layup process is faster than hand layup and involves feeding a stream of chopped fibers into a spray of liquid plastic in a mold cavity,Irrelevant
The direction of the fibers is random and the process is usually automated,Irrelevant
After layup is completed the plastic must solidify or cure in a reasonable time at room temperature which occurs via chemical reactions,Relevant
A group or array of one or more receiver or decoder printed circuit boards is run through a machine called a solder printer,Relevant

Printed circuit boards (PCB) are thin stiff pieces of electrically nonconducting material onto which a pattern of electricallyconducting material has been bonded to form numerous circuit paths much like flat wires,Irrelevant
Electronic components are attached to both sides of the board and interconnected by the printed circuitry,Relevant
The solder printer is programmed to apply a small amount of solder paste to the points where the components will make electrical contact with the printed circuits,Relevant
The PCBs are then processed through another machine known as a highspeed chip shooter,Relevant
The shooter quickly and accurately places or shoots the majority of the pagers small components onto each board,Relevant
After a visual inspection the PCBs are run through a series of robotic placement machines which place the larger and oddshaped parts onto the boards,Relevant
These include the integrated circuit (IC) chips oscillators and crystal filters,Irrelevant
Once all these parts have been placed the boards are run through a reflow oven,Relevant
In this oven the solder paste melts or reflows to form an electrical connection between the components and the printed circuits,Relevant
The board arrays are then given a final visual inspection for defects and are sent through the singulation process in which the individual boards are cut from the array and labeled,Relevant
Some pagers require parts which must be placed by hand in a process called post reflow assembly,Irrelevant
These parts are generally too large for robotic placement or too sensitive to the extreme heat of the reflow oven,Irrelevant
The liquid crystal display (LCD) is attached to the decoder board and the decoder board with the LCD is placed Beeperinto the plastic outer housing,Relevant
The housing also contains the onoff switch belt fastener clip and battery compartment with electrical contacts,Irrelevant
At this point the pagers have none of their specific features,Irrelevant
They have not been assigned a radio frequency nor have they been programmed with a unique telephone number or any customer options,Irrelevant
All of that will happen in the back end process,Irrelevant
First a crystal is soldered to the receiver board,Relevant
A crystal is an electronic component which can be activated only by a specific radio frequency,Irrelevant
The crystal is selected to match the radio frequency assigned to the pager,Irrelevant

The receiver board is then connected to the decoder board inside the pager housing and the housing is sent through a laser which is programmed to etch the pager identification number and other data onto the back cover of the housing,Relevant
The pager is sent to the programming station where it is automatically programmed with a unique identification number and a large spectrum of options selected by the customer,Relevant
The After programming the pager crystal and filter frequencies are tuned at a manual tuning station,Relevant
This ensures the pager will receive the exact radio frequency assigned to it and prevents reception of messages intended for other pagers on other frequencies,Relevant
Sometimes this process is done automatically,Irrelevant
In the final assembly station the back I cover is secured onto the decoder board a battery is inserted and the pager is turned on,Relevant
After passing a radio frequency test and a final visual inspection the pager is packed and sent to the customer,Relevant
Fully ripened barley grains are steeped or soaked in cold water until they are fully saturated,Relevant
The water is changed once a day and after 4572 hours the grains are placed in shallow tanks,Relevant
The grain is aerated and stirred which causes it to germinate releasing enzymes such as malt diastase,Relevant
Malt diastase converts the starches contained in the grain to sugar for fermentation,Relevant
As soon as the germination is adequately complete usually six days the grain is roasted to stop the germination process,Relevant
The exact point at which the roasting starts and ends affects the flavor and color of the beer,Relevant
The product at this point is referred to as malt,Relevant
The automatic canning machinery dwarfs the workers in this 1970s brewery canning room,Irrelevant
(From the collections of Henry Ford Museum Greenfield Village),Irrelevant
The automatic canning machinery dwarfs the workers in this 1970s brewery canning room,Irrelevant
The malt is crushed using iron rollers and transferred to the mash tank (or tun),Irrelevant
This tank is a large copper or stainless steel vessel that mixes the malt with warm water until it is of porridgelike consistency,Irrelevant
This mixture is called mash,Irrelevant
After mixing with similarly prepared cereal grains the temperature of the mash is raised incrementally from 100170°F (3877°C) so that the enzymes react,Relevant
The enzymes break down the starch in the grain and convert it to simple sugars,Relevant
Later the yeast will convert the sugars into alcohol,Relevant
Once complete the mash is allowed to sit undisturbed so the solids can descend to the bottom of the tank,Relevant
Beer requires these ingredients for proper brewing prepared cereal grain (usually barley and corn or rice) hops pure water and brewers yeast,Irrelevant
Each ingredient can affect flavor color carbonation alcohol content and other subtle changes in the beer,Irrelevant
The liquid contained in the mash is transferred into another tank called a lauter tun,Relevant
This is accomplished by drawing the liquid out through the bottom layer of mash solids which acts as a filter,Relevant
Hot water is added to the top of the mash tank to rinse the remaining liquid now called wort from the mash,Relevant
The solid remains of the grain are dried and sold by the brewery as animal feed,Relevant
The wort travels on to the brew kettles where it is boiled to sterilize it and where the carefully prepared hops are added,Relevant
The addition of the hops is important because they contribute to the bitterness of the beer,Irrelevant
The brew kettles are the most impressive equipment in the process,Irrelevant
Gleaming copper they can be 712 feet (236 m) in diameter and two stories high,Irrelevant
Steam usually provides the heating energy to the brew kettles,Irrelevant
After brewing is complete the finished wort is filtered again and pumped to the fermentation tanks,Relevant
In the fermentation tanks the atmosphere must be carefully controlled to prevent any rouge bacteria from interfering with the yeast,Irrelevant

Carefully maintained yeast (approximately one pound per barrel of wort) is added to the wort and the temperature of the mixture is slowly reduced over a period of days to between 50°F and 60°F (1015°C),Irrelevant
In this temperature range the yeast grows consuming the sugar in the wort and bubbles of carbon dioxide form,Irrelevant
The wort has now become beer,Irrelevant
The new beer is filtered and transferred once more into the aging casks where the temperature is controlled at 33°F (°C) for 224 weeks,Relevant
The shorter storage time produces a pale lager beer while the European lagers (called BeerPilsner) are aged longer to increase the alcohol content,Irrelevant
After aging the beer can be pasteurized to kill the remaining yeast and prevent further alcohol production,Relevant
This is accomplished by heating the beer above 135°F (57°C),Relevant
This process named after Louis Pasteur is widely known for preserving milk,Irrelevant
Interestingly Pasteur originally developed this process to preserve beer in the 1860s,Irrelevant
Pasteurization however is not used in the production of genuine draft beers,Irrelevant
These beers are also known as ice beers since they must be kept refrigerated to preserve their flavor and slow the remaining yeast activity,Irrelevant
Many consider the draft beers best in aroma as well as taste,Irrelevant
Whether packaged into cans bottles or kegs the beer is always moved gently through the maze of piping in the bottling area,Irrelevant
This is to preserve the natural carbonation,Irrelevant
During bottling additional carbon dioxide gas from the fermentation kettles is used to improve the aroma of the beer,Relevant
Highspeed packaging lines can process thousands of cases of beer per day and with modern computerized control the inventory can be tracked throughout the distribution network,Irrelevant
Most beer is delivered from local distributors who have purchasing contracts with the major breweries,Irrelevant

Most beer is available in the following package sizes pony cans and bottles of about 8 fluid ounces standard 12ounce cans and bottles 16 and 32ounce jumbo cans 40ounce picnic bottles 8gallon pony kegs and the standard 16gallon beer keg,Irrelevant
Other novelty and party packages are also available,Irrelevant
Cans and bottles are packed in 6 8 12 or 24 each to a box or case,Relevant
Most states require a deposit at point of sale to encourage the return of the bottles and cans,Relevant
When beer is dispensed from the keg a pressure apparatus called a tapper is used to apply a light pressure of carbon dioxide (usually 26 PSI) to the tapper head for dispensing,Relevant
The craft of casting bells has remained essentially the same since the 12th century,Irrelevant
BellThe one singular innovation was the invention of the tuning machine in the 19th century,Irrelevant
Prior to that time the proper tone was achieved by chipping the sides of the bell with a hammer and chisel,Irrelevant
This procedure carried a high risk of damaging the bell,Irrelevant
The tuning machine which is essentially a vertical lathe has reduced that risk,Irrelevant
Electronic tuning machines have increased the bell founders ability to test the accuracy of the bells tone,Irrelevant
All in all however creating a bell is still very much a handson process,Irrelevant
Using the specifications submitted by the purchaser the bellmaker determines the shape that the bell will need to take in order to resonate with the proper number of vibrations,Irrelevant
After estimating the required weight the bellmaker orders the metal,Relevant
These are painstaking measurements that can take several weeks of calculations to accomplish,Irrelevant
The bellmaker cuts out two wooden templates called strickle boards,Relevant
One of the boards matches the dimensions of the outer bell (called the case or cope) the other matches that of the inner bell (called the core),Relevant
These templates are used to construct the mold,Relevant
An exact stone model of the outer bell sometimes called a false bell is covered first with sand or loam then with molten wax,Irrelevant
Figures and inscriptions also made of wax are applied by hand,Relevant
The false bell is Bellpainted over with three coats of very fine fireproof clay,Irrelevant
It is then enclosed in a steel mantle that has been lowered by rope pulleys,Relevant
The space between the false bell and the mantle is filled with cement,Relevant
After the cement has hardened the mantle is lifted off the cement mold,Relevant
The false bell under the mold is chipped away,Relevant
Any remaining scraps of the false bell are removed with a blow torch,Relevant
The mold is then set over a coke fire to melt the remaining wax and to evaporate any water that has accumulated,Relevant
A model of the inner bell is constructed of stone and coated with fireproof cement,Relevant
It is then smoothed to remove any irregularities,Relevant
After the mantle has been cleaned it is again lowered over the outer bell model,Relevant
The mantle and the outer bell mold are then lowered over the inner mold,Relevant
The outer and inner sections are clamped together leaving a space between them and set into a pit,Relevant
Ingots of bronze are melted in oil burners and heated to a temperature of approximately 1150°F (1100°C),Relevant
The molten metal is skimmed to remove impurities and then poured into drums,Relevant
The drums are carried to the pit and carefully tipped so that the hot metal flows into the space between the two molds,Relevant
Holes in the top of the mantle allow gases to escape,Irrelevant
If the gases remained in the metal the bell would be too porous and easily cracked,Irrelevant
The bell is allowed to cool for several days,Relevant
Large bells can take as much as a week to cool completely,Irrelevant
Small bells usually classified as those under 500 pounds (227 kg) can be removed from the molding pit the next day,Irrelevant
The bell is cast with slightly thicker sides so that the bell can be ground as it twirls slowly upside down on a circular lathe to acquire the precise tone,Relevant
The bell tuner is highly skilled it takes years of experience to know just how much metal to remove,Relevant
The bell tone is tested frequently during the tuning process using an electronic device that registers the vibrations as the bell is struck,Relevant
If the tone is too low the lathe operator grinds more metal off the lower edge of the bell,Relevant
If the tone is too high the bell is thinned with a file,Relevant
The clapper is manufactured in much the same manner as the bell itself,Relevant
Special care is given to cast the clapper at the proper weight,Relevant
A clapper that is too lightweight will not bring out the true tones of the bell,Irrelevant
A heavy clapper might cause the bell to crack,Irrelevant
Holes are drilled into the top of the bell,Relevant
Using mounting bolts and supports the clapper is fastened to the bell,Relevant
Seamless frame tubes are constructed from solid blocks of steel that are pierced and drawn into tubes through several stages,Relevant
These are usually superior to seamed tubes which are made by drawing flat steel strip stock wrapping it into a tube and welding it together along the length of the tube,Irrelevant
Seamless tubes may then be further manipulated to increase their strength and decrease their weight by butting or altering the thickness of the tube walls,Irrelevant

Butting involves increasing the thickness of the walls at the joints or ends of the tube where the most stress is delivered and thinning the walls at the center of the tube where there is relatively little stress,Relevant
Butted tubing also improves the resiliency of the frame,Irrelevant

Butted tubes may be singlebutted with one end thicker doublebutted with both ends thicker than the center triplebutted with different thicknesses at either end and quadbutted similar to a triple but with the center thinning towards the middle,Irrelevant
Constant thickness tubes however are also appropriate for certain bikes,Irrelevant
The tubes are assembled into a frame by handbrazing or welding by machine the former being a more laborintensive process and therefore more expensive,Relevant
Composites may be joined with strong glue or plastic binders,Irrelevant
The components are generally manufactured by machine and may be attached to the frame by hand or machine,Irrelevant
Final adjustments are made by skilled bicycle builders,Irrelevant
The metal is annealed or softened by heating and hollowed out to form hollows or blooms,Relevant
These are heated again pickled in acid to remove scale and lubricated,Relevant
The hollows are measured cut and precision mitered to the appropriate dimensions,Relevant
Frame sizes for adult bicycles generally run from 1925 inches (4863 cm) from the top of the seat post tube to the middle of the crank hanger,Irrelevant
Next the hollows are fitted over a mandrel or rod attached to a draw bench,Relevant
To achieve the right gauge the hollows pass through dies which stretch them into thinner and longer tubes a process called cold drawing,Relevant
The tubes may be shaped and tapered into a variety of designs and lengths,Irrelevant
The tapergauge fork blades may have to pass through more than a dozen operations to achieve the correct strength weight and resilience,Irrelevant
Tubes can be joined into a frame either by hand or machine,Irrelevant
Frames may be brazed welded or glued with or without lugs which are the metal sleeves joining two or more tubes at a joint,Relevant
Brazing is essentially welding at a temperature of about 1600°F (871°C) or lower,Relevant
Gas burners are arranged evenly around the lugs which are heated forming a white flux that melts and cleans the surface preparing it for brazing,Irrelevant
The brazing filler is generally brass (copperzinc alloy) or silver which melt at lower temperatures than the tubes being joined,Relevant
The filler is applied and as it melts it flows around the joint sealing it,Relevant
The assembled frames are placed into jigs and checked for proper alignment,Relevant
Adjustments are made while the frame is still hot and malleable,Relevant
The excess flux and brazing metals are cleaned off by pickling in acid solutions and by washing and grinding the brazing until it is smooth,Relevant
After the metals have cooled further precision alignments are made,Relevant
The frames are painted not only to create a more finished appearance but also to protect the frame,Relevant
The frame is first primed with an undercoat and then painted with a colored enamel,Relevant
Paint may be applied by handspraying or by passing the frames through automatic electrostatic spraying rooms,Irrelevant
The negatively charged frames attract the positively charged paint spray as the frames rotate for full coverage,Irrelevant
Finally transfers and lacquer are applied to the frame,Relevant
Chrome plating may also be used instead of paint on components such as the fork blades,Relevant
The manufacture of sodium hypochlorite bleach requires several steps,Irrelevant
All the steps can be carried out at one large manufacturing facility or the chlorine and caustic soda can be shipped from different plants to the reactor site,Irrelevant
Both chlorine and caustic soda are hazardous chemicals and are transported according to strict regulations,Relevant
Caustic soda is usually produced and shipped as a concentrated 50 solution,Irrelevant
At its destination this concentrated solution is diluted with water to form a new 25 solution,Relevant
Heat is created when the water dilutes the strong caustic soda solution,Relevant
The diluted caustic soda is cooled before it is reacted,Relevant
Chlorine and the caustic soda solution are reacted to form sodium hypochlorite bleach,Relevant
This reaction can take place in a batch of about 14000 gallons or in a continuous reactor,Irrelevant
To create sodium hypochlorite liquid or gaseous chlorine is circulated through the caustic soda solution,Irrelevant
The reaction of chlorine and caustic soda is essentially instantaneous,Irrelevant
The bleach solution is then cooled to help prevent decomposition,Relevant
Often this cooled bleach is settled or filtered to remove impurities that can discolor the bleach or catalyze its decomposition,Relevant
The finished sodium hypochlorite bleach is shipped to a bottling plant or bottled onsite,Relevant
Householdstrength bleach is typically 525 sodium hypochlorite in an aqueous solution,Relevant
The sifted flour is poured into an industrial mixer,Relevant
Temperaturecontrolled water Breadis piped into the mixer,Irrelevant
This mixture is called gluten and gives bread its elasticity,Irrelevant
A premeasured amount of yeast is added,Relevant
Yeast is actually a tiny organism which feeds off the sugars in the grain and emits carbon dioxide,Irrelevant
The growth of the yeast produces gas bubbles which leaven the bread,Relevant
