Some manufacturers cut a small rectangle of glass from each run in order to provide a sample of each color to their customers,Irrelevant
There are hundreds of colors tints and patterns available as well as a number of different textures of cathedral glass,Irrelevant
Different textures are produced by changing the roller to one having the desired texture,Irrelevant
Glass manufacturers are continuously introducing new colors and types of glass to meet the demands of their customers,Irrelevant
Though some of the tools to make stained glass windows have been improved the windows are still hand crafted as they were centuries ago,Irrelevant
The first step of the process involves the artist creating a small scale version of the final design,Relevant
After the design has been approved the craftsperson takes measurements or templates of the actual window openings to create a pattern,Relevant
This pattern is usually drawn on paper or cardboard and is the actual size of the spaces to be filled with glass,Relevant
Next a fullsized drawing called the cartoon is prepared in black and white,Relevant
From the cartoon the cutline and pattern drawings are made,Relevant
The modern cutline drawing is a careful exact tracing of the leadlines of the cartoon on heavy paper,Relevant
The leadlines are the outlines of the shapes for patterns to which the glass is to be cut,Irrelevant
This drawing serves as the guide for the subsequent placing and binding with lead of the many pieces of glass,Irrelevant
The patterndrawing is a carbon copy of the cutline drawing,Irrelevant

It is cut along the black or lead lines with doublebladed scissors or a knife which as it passes through the middle of the black lines simultaneously cuts away a narrow strip of paper thus allowing sufficient space between the segment of glass for the core of the grooved lead,Relevant
This core is the supporting wall between the upper and lower flanges of the lead,Irrelevant
Colored glass is then selected from the supply on hand,Relevant
The pattern is placed on a piece of the desired color and with a diamond or steel wheel the glass is cut to the shape of the pattern,Relevant
After the glass has been cut the main outlines of the cartoon are painted on each piece of glass with special paint called vitrifiable paint,Relevant
This becomes glassy when heated,Irrelevant
The painter might apply further paint to the glass in order to control the light and bring all the colors into closer harmony,Relevant
During this painting process the glass is held up to the light to simulate the same conditions in which the window will be seen,Relevant
The painted pieces are fired in the kiln at least once to fuse the paint and glass,Relevant
The next step is glazing,Irrelevant
The cutline drawing is spread out on a table and narrow strips of wood called laths are nailed down along two edges of the drawing to form a right angle,Relevant
Long strips of grooved lead are placed along the inside of the laths,Relevant
The piece of glass belonging in the angle is fitted into the grooves,Relevant
A strip of narrow lead is fitted around the exposed edge or edges and the next required segment slipped into the groove on the other side of the narrow lead,Irrelevant
This is continued until each piece has been inserted into the leads in its proper place according to the outline drawing beneath,Irrelevant
The many joints formed by the leading are then soldered on both sides and the entire window is waterproofed,Relevant
After the completed window has been thoroughly inspected in the light the sections are packed and shipped to their destination where they are installed and secured with reinforcing bars,Relevant
For faceted glass windows the process begins the same way with the cutline and pattern drawings being made with carbons in a similar manner,Irrelevant
The pattern drawing is then cut to the actual size of the piece of glass with ordinary scissors since there is no core of lead to allow for,Relevant
The thick glass slabs next are cut with a sharp doubleedged hammer to the shape of the pattern,Relevant
To give the slab an interesting texture the worker then chips round depressions in the glass with the same hammer,Relevant
This is called faceting,Irrelevant
Instead of glazing with lead a matrix of concrete or epoxy is poured around the pieces of glass,Relevant
The glass pieces have first been glued to the outline drawing which is covered with a heavy coating of transparent grease so that the paper can be removed after the epoxy sets,Relevant
The whole is enclosed within a wooden form which is the exact size and shape of the section being made,Relevant
The worker must wear gloves during this process since epoxy resin is a toxic material,Irrelevant
After hardening the section is cleaned and cured prior to shipping and installation,Relevant
The process for making an entire stained glass window can take anywhere from seven to ten weeks since everything must be done by hand,Irrelevant
Cost can vary widely depending on complexity and size though some windows can be created for a cost as low as $500,Irrelevant
The customer can choose an existing pattern rather than create an entirely new one to minimize costs,Irrelevant
In this case the pattern can be customized by altering shapes or by changing the placement of the central image,Relevant
Sunscreen products may be manufactured bottled and shipped from a single facility or portions of this work may be handled outside of the company,Irrelevant
The fully automated manufacturing process described here uses some of both approaches,Irrelevant
Water is purified using a method called reverse osmosis,Irrelevant
Reverse osmosis extracts pure fresh water by forcing water under pressure through a semipermeable membrane which separates pure water molecules from salts and other impurities,Relevant
Ingredients are purchased from outside sources and mixed with the purified water according to the recipe of the final formulation,Relevant
The recipe is recorded on a vat sheet which lists the exact measurements for each ingredient,Irrelevant
Measurements are converted from the initial 10gallon (38 1) recipe used in the development stage to larger quantities for commercial use,Irrelevant
A blow molding facility manufactures the plastic containers for the sunscreen,Irrelevant
In some cases this is done outside of the company,Irrelevant
Blow molding is a method in which thermoplastics plastics which soften when heated and harden when cooled are extruded into a tube called a parison and placed into an open mold,Irrelevant
The mold is closed around the heated parison and the parison is pinched at the bottom to form a seal,Relevant
Compressed air is blown through the top of the parison which forces the softened plastic to expand to the inside walls of the mold creating the shape of the container,Relevant
Containers are moved to a printing facility where logos and product information are printed and in some cases stamped onto the containers,Relevant
Stamping embosses thin metal foil onto the surface of the container in the desired shape usually a logo,Relevant
The printed or stamped containers are then stored for use when needed,Irrelevant
Stainless steel tanks with capacities up to 1000 gallons (3784 1) are used in the filling process,Irrelevant
Filling takes place in a separate sterile room with a conveyor system of many incoming tracks,Irrelevant
Machine operators monitor the automated process,Irrelevant
Containers and caps enter the fill room on conveyor tracks,Irrelevant

The sunscreen lotion flows from the vats through stainless steel piping to a pressure filling machine which inserts a retractable nozzle into each container and fills it with a measured amount of sunscreen lotion,Relevant
Most containers are capped automatically along the production line,Relevant
Some containers include caps with pumps to allow easy dispensing of the sunscreen,Relevant
These pump caps require manual assembly by operators as the containers leave the fill phase,Relevant
The filled and capped containers are boxed in quantities of 12 to be pelletized and secured to a skid by shrink wrapping for transport to distributors,Relevant
Most surfboards are built one at a time in small surfboard shops,Irrelevant
Although techniques and materials vary from one surfboard builder to another the following is a typical process,Irrelevant
The foam core or blank is formed in a large cement mold roughly the shape of the surfboard,Irrelevant
The mold is constructed in two halves and the inside is lined with a special paper that keeps the foam from sticking to the mold,Relevant
The two halves are clamped together and the mold is heated,Relevant
When the liquid polyurethane chemicals are poured into the mold the heat triggers a chemical reaction which begins forming a dense white foam,Relevant
Surfboard builders call this process blowing the blank,Irrelevant
After 25 minutes the mold is opened and the foam core is taken out and allowed to finish hardening ,Relevant
Once the core is hard it is cut in half vertically from the nose to the tail ,Relevant
A thin stringer is glued between the two halves and the core is then clamped back together to dry ,Relevant
Stringers provide stiffness and help keep the board from breaking in half ,Relevant
The outline of the finished board is traced onto the rough core using a wooden template as a guide ,Relevant
The outline is then cut out with a saber saw ,Relevant
Starting with the bottom of the blank the surface is smoothed and contoured to its final shape with a power planer ,Relevant
There are no templates or automatic machines to do this job just the trained eye and experienced touch of the surfboard builder ,Irrelevant
When the bottom is finished the board is flipped over and the top is shaped,Relevant
A power sander removes any ridges left by the planer and the stringer is contoured with a hand plane ,Relevant
Rough sandpaper is used to shape the sides or rails ,Relevant
The blank is given a final sanding with fine paper the position for the fin is marked and the builder signs the blank with a special design or signature ,Relevant
The shaped blank is now ready to be covered with fiberglass and resin to form the hard outer shell of the surfboard ,Relevant
First the blank is blown clean with compressed air ,Relevant
If the board is to be colored or have a design on it acrylic paint is applied directly to the foam with a spray gun or airbrush ,Relevant
When the paint is dry fiberglass cloth is laid over the surface of the blank and cut to fit ,Relevant
The top of the board or deck is laminated first ,Relevant
A polyester resin known as a laminating resin is mixed with a second chemical called a catalyst ,Relevant
This starts a chemical reaction which will cause the resin to harden in 15 minutes ,Relevant
The resin is poured over the fiberglass and spread evenly using a rubber squeegee ,Relevant
All of the fiberglass must be covered without leaving too much or too little resin in any spot ,Irrelevant
This process is known as glassing ,Irrelevant
When the deck is finished the board is flipped over and the process repeated on the bottom ,Relevant
The board is then flipped once more and the deck is given a second layer of fiberglass and resin for added strength and wear resistance ,Relevant
The laminating resin remains slightly tacky and rubbery when dry,Irrelevant
A second coat of resin called the filler coat or sanding resin is applied next ,Relevant
The filler coat fills any surface imperfections left in the laminating resin ,Irrelevant
Sometimes this coat is called a hot coat resin and contains wax ,Irrelevant
In either case this resin contains a slightly different mix of chemicals which cause it to harden completely ,Irrelevant
The deck is coated first and the board is flipped over ,Relevant
The fin is secured with fiberglass tape and a laminating resin ,Relevant
When the fin resin is dry the bottom of the board and the fin are given a filler coat ,Relevant
When both sides are dry a small hole is drilled through the tail to attach the leg leash ,Relevant
The leg leash is an elastic cord sometimes made of surgical rubber tubing that the surfer attaches to one ankle ,Relevant
The leg leash keeps the board from floating away when the surfer falls or wipes out,Relevant
Any excess resin must be carefully sanded away,Relevant
A power sander is used for the broad surfaces but the rails and other sharply contoured surfaces are hand sanded to avoid gouging into the fiberglass layer,Relevant
The board is blown clean with compressed air to remove any residual sanding dust,Relevant
On some boards decals or color graphics are added at this point,Relevant
A final coat of gloss resin is then brushed onto the board,Relevant
Like the other two layers of resin this final gloss coat is mixed with a catalyst and will harden within 15 minutes,Relevant
The board is set aside for at least 12 hours to allow the gloss coat to completely harden,Relevant
As a final step the board may be wet sanded with very fine sandpaper then rubbed buffed and polished,Relevant
Making Tshirts is a fairly simple and largely automated process,Irrelevant
Specially designed machines integrate cutting assembling and stitching for the most efficient operations,Irrelevant
The most commonly used seams for Tshirts are narrow superimposed seams which are usually made by placing one piece of fabric onto another and lining up the seam edges,Irrelevant
These seams are frequently stitched with an overedge stitch which requires one needle thread from above and two looper threads from below,Irrelevant
This particular seam and stitch combination results in a flexible finished seam,Irrelevant
Another type of seam that may be used for Tshirts are bound seams in which a narrow piece of fabric is folded around a seam as at the neckline,Irrelevant
These seams may be stitched together using a lockstitch chainstitch or overedge stitch,Irrelevant
Depending on the style of the Tshirt the order in which the garment is assembled may vary slightly,Irrelevant
The Tshirt style is designed and the dimensions are transferred to patterns,Relevant
Adjustments are made for size differences and stylistic preferences,Relevant
The Tshirt sections are cut to the dimensions of the patterns,Relevant
The pieces consist of a tubed body or separate front and back sections sleeves perhaps pockets and trim,Irrelevant
For fabric that is not tubed the separate pieces for the front and back sections must be stitched together at the sides,Irrelevant
They are joined at the seam lines to form a simple narrow superimposed seam and stitched together using an overedge stitch,Relevant
Care must be taken to avoid a needle cutting the yarn of the fabric which can lead to tears in the garment,Irrelevant
The hems of sleeves are generally finished before they are fitted into the garment since it is easier to hem the fabric while it is flat,Irrelevant
An automated system moves the sleeves to the sewing head by conveyor,Relevant
The edge may be finished by folding it over forming the hem and stitching or by applying a band,Relevant
The band may be attached as a superimposed seam or folded over the edge as binding,Relevant
If the Tshirt body is tubular the sleeve material is first sewn together and then set into the garment,Irrelevant
Alternatively if the Tshirt is cut and sewn the unseamed sleeve is set into place,Irrelevant
Later during the final stage of sewing the shirt the sleeve and side seams are sewn in one action,Irrelevant
The garment hem is commonly sewn with an overedge stitch resulting in a flexible hem,Relevant
The tension of the stitch should be loose enough to allow stretching the garment without tearing the fabric,Irrelevant
Alternative hem styles include a combination of edge finishing stitches,Irrelevant
Pockets may be sewn onto Tshirts intended for casual wear,Relevant
Higher quality Tshirts will insert an interlining into the pocket so that it maintains its shape,Irrelevant
The interlining is inserted into the pocket as it is sewn onto the Tshirt front,Relevant
Pockets may be attached to the garment with automated setters so the operator only has to arrange the fabric pieces and the mechanical setter positions the pocket and stitches the seam,Relevant
Generally shoulder seams require a simple superimposed seam,Irrelevant
Higher quality Tshirt manufacturers may reinforce seams with tape or elastic,Relevant
Depending on the style of the Tshirt the seams at the shoulder may be completed before or after the neckband is attached,Irrelevant
For instance if a tubular neckband is to be applied the shoulder seams must first be closed,Irrelevant
For crew neck shirts the neck edge should be slightly shorter in circumference than the outer edge where it is attached to the garment,Irrelevant
Thus the neckband must be stretched just the right amount to prevent bulging,Irrelevant
Tubular neckbands are applied manually,Irrelevant
The bands are folded wrong sides together stretched slightly and aligned with the neckline,Relevant
The superimposed seam is stitched with an overedge stitch,Relevant
Bound seams are finished with a cover stitch and are easy to achieve,Relevant
Bound seams may be used on a variety of neckline styles,Irrelevant
The process entails feeding ribbed fabric through machines which fold the fabric and apply tension to it,Irrelevant
Some neckbands on lowerpriced shirts are attached separately to the front and back necklines of the garment,Relevant
Thus when the shoulder seams are stitched seams are visible on the neckband,Irrelevant
Vnecks require the extra step of either lapping or mitering the neckband,Irrelevant
In the former process one side is folded over the other,Irrelevant
A mitered seam is more complex requiring an operator to overlap the band accurately and stitch the band at center front,Irrelevant
An easier method for a Vneck look is to attach the band to the neckline and then sew a tuck to form a V,Irrelevant
Necklines with superimposed seams may be taped so that the shirt is stronger and more comfortable,Irrelevant
Tape may be extended across the back and over the shoulder seams to reinforce this area as well and to flatten the seam,Irrelevant
The seam is then cover stitched or top stitched,Relevant
One or more labels are usually attached at the back of the neckline,Relevant
Labels provide information about the manufacturer size fabric content and washing instructions,Relevant
Some Tshirts will have trim or screen prints added for decorative purposes,Relevant
Special Tshirts for infants have larger openings at the head,Relevant
The shoulder seams are left open near the neck and buttons or other fasteners are attached,Irrelevant
Tshirts are inspected for flaws in the fabric stitching and thread,Relevant
Highquality Tshirts may be pressed through steam tunnels before they are packaged,Relevant
Packaging depends on the type of Tshirt and the intended distribution outlet,Irrelevant
For underwear the shirts are folded and packaged in preprinted bags usually of clear plastic that list information about the product,Relevant
Shirts may be boarded or folded around a piece of cardboard so that they maintain their shape during shipping and on the shelf,Relevant
Finally they are placed into boxes by the dozen or halfdozen,Relevant
Traditional withering practices call for manually spreading the leaves in thin layers and exposing them to the open air for 1820 hours,Irrelevant
Modern factory methods place the leaves in troughs perforated drums or tunnels and expose them to mechanical blasts of hot air,Relevant
This process oxidizes the polyphenols or tannins the primary active ingredient and turns the tea leaves a coppery color,Relevant
The leaves are crushed either by hand or on rotating tables called rolling machines,Relevant
Either method twists the leaves so that they are eventually coated with their own juices and torn into smaller pieces,Relevant
Some companies employ hightech machinery similar to tobaccocutting machines to crush and tear the tea leaves,Irrelevant
Black tea leaves are mechanically dried using a hightemperature method to seal in juices and flavor,Relevant
This process turns the leaves to their characteristic black color,Irrelevant
Oolong tea leaves are rolled dried and rolled again,Relevant
The drying time is shorter than that for black tea therefore the fermentation is less natural and half or less of the polyphenols are oxidized,Relevant
Green tea leaves are steamed within 24 hours of harvesting using either moist or dry heat in perforated drums or hot iron pans,Relevant
This process destroys enzymes and prevents fermentation and the oxidation of polyphenols,Irrelevant
Herb tea is simply bundled together and hung upside down to air dry,Relevant
After the leaves are dried they are brought to a mill room where they are cut with a rotating blade into varying degrees of fineness depending on the type of tea,Relevant
The cut leaves are further refined by sifting them through mechanical sieves with meshes of varying grades,Relevant
The tea used in tea bags are typically brokengrade or smallsized teas because they require a shorter brewing time,Irrelevant
The leaves are blended according to company recipes to achieve a uniform taste and texture,Relevant
Most teas are a blend of between 2040 types of tea leaves,Irrelevant

The blending process may also include the addition of natural flavorings such as cinnamon orange peel nutmeg cloves chocolate licorice root peppermint ginger crushed hibiscus flowers fennel seeds and chicory root,Relevant
The processed and blended tea leaves are stored in hoppers that hold up to 800 pounds (363 kg) of tea,Relevant
Flow tubes connect each hopper to a doser wheel,Irrelevant
The doser wheel resembles a Ferris wheel with small chambers in the place of seats,Irrelevant
Air pushes the leaves through the flow tube and into the wheel which separates the tea into the chambers in premeasured amounts usually two grams,Relevant
Two large rolls of filter paper are fed over the top and underneath the doser wheel,Relevant
As each chamber arrives at the bottom of the doser wheel it releases the tea onto the bottom paper layer of paper as it moves along a conveyer belt,Relevant
The top layer of paper is lowered onto the lower layer so that each measure of tea is sandwiched between the two layers,Relevant
A conveyer belt moves the three components to a heatsealing drum fitted with an indentation pattern,Relevant
The drum quickly seals the paper along the indentation lines,Relevant
The timing of this process is closely monitored because too much heat would adversely affect the tea,Relevant
The sealed paper continues along a conveyer belt until it reaches a perforation blade that is calibrated to cut the paper into precise squares,Relevant
After a string and tag are stapled to the bag they are dropped into preprinted boxes,Relevant
Metal hardware components are manufactured using standard metalworking machines such as lathes and drill presses,Irrelevant
Components made from ABS plastics (usually the external body of the telescope) are produced using a technique known as injection molding,Irrelevant
In this process the plastic is melted and forced under pressure into a mold in the shape of the final product,Relevant
The plastic is allowed to cool back into a solid and the mold is opened to allow the component to be removed,Relevant
The glass manufacturer mixes the proper raw materials with waste glass of the same type as the glass to be made,Relevant
This waste glass known as cullet acts as a flux that is it causes the raw materials to react together at a lower temperature than they would without it,Irrelevant
This mixture is heated in a glass furnace until it has melted into a liquid,Relevant
The temperature needed to form molten glass varies with the type of glass being made but it is typically about 2550°F (1400°C),Irrelevant
The temperature of the molten glass is raised to about 2820°F (1550°C) to force air bubbles to come to the surface,Relevant
It is then allowed to cool while being stirred constantly until it has reached about 1830°F (1000°C) at which point it is an extremely thick fluid,Relevant
This viscous molten glass is poured into molds with roughly the same shape as the lenses required,Relevant

After the glass has cooled to about 570°F (300°C) it must be reheated to about 1020°F (550°C) to remove internal stresses that form during the initial cooling period and which weaken the glass,Relevant
It is then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature,Relevant
This process is known as annealing,Irrelevant
The final lensshaped chunks of glass are known as blanks,Relevant
The blanks are processed by the telescope manufacturer in three steps cutting grinding and polishing,Relevant
A mirror is formed in exactly the same way as a lens until the reflective coating is applied,Relevant

First a highspeed rotating cylindrical cutter with a round diamond blade known as a curve generator shaves the surface of the lens until a close approximation of the desired curve is achieved,Relevant
The cut lens is inspected with a spherometer to check the curvature and is recut if necessary,Relevant
The time required for cutting varies greatly with the type of glass being cut and the kind of lens being shaped,Irrelevant
A lens may require several cuttings each of which may take anywhere from a few minutes to more than half an hour,Irrelevant
Several cut blanks are placed on a curved block in such a way that their surfaces line up as if they were all part of one large spherical curve,Relevant
This is necessary so that the grinding machine can grind them all in the same way,Irrelevant
A cast iron grinding surface known as a tool is pressed onto them,Relevant
During grinding the block of lenses rotates while the tool is free to move at random on top of it,Irrelevant

Between the tool and the block flows a slurry containing water an abrasive to do the grinding (usually silicon carbide) a coolant to prevent the lenses from being damaged by overheating and a surfactant to keep the abrasive from settling out,Irrelevant

The speed at which the block rotates the force placed on the lenses the exact contents of the slurry and other variables are controlled by experienced opticians to produce the exact type of lens desired,Relevant
Each lens is once again inspected with a spherometer and reground if necessary,Relevant
The total grinding process may take anywhere from one hour to eight hours,Irrelevant
The ground lenses are cleaned and moved to the polishing room,Relevant
The polishing machine is similar to the grinding machine but the tool is made from pitch—a thick soft resinous substance derived from coal tar or wood tar,Relevant

A pitch tool is made by placing tape around the circumference of a curved dish pouring in hot liquid pitch with other ingredients such as beeswax and jewelers rouge and letting it cool back into a solid,Relevant
A pitch tool can polish about 50 lenses before it must be reshaped,Irrelevant
Polishing proceeds in the same manner as grinding but instead of an abrasive the slurry contains a polishing substance usually cerium dioxide in the form of a very fine pink powder,Irrelevant
The polished lenses are optically inspected and repolished if necessary,Relevant
The polishing procedure may take anywhere from half an hour to four or five hours,Irrelevant
The lenses are cleaned and are ready for coating,Relevant
To make a lens into a mirror a very thin very smooth coating of aluminum is applied,Relevant
Aluminum is heated in a vacuum to form a vapor,Relevant
A negative electrostatic charge is applied to the surface of the lens so that the positively charged aluminum ions are attracted to it,Relevant

Similar procedures are followed to apply a coating of silicon dioxide to protect the fragile surface of a mirror or to apply an antireflective coating of magnesium fluoride to the surface of a lens,Irrelevant
The finished lens or mirror is inspected labeled with a date of manufacture and a serial number and stored until needed,Relevant
The hardware components lenses and mirrors required to make a particular model of telescope are assembled by hand in an assembly line process,Relevant
The completed telescope is packed with closefitting expanded polystyrene foam to protect it from damage during shipping,Relevant
The telescope is packed in a cardboard box and shipped to the retailer or consumer,Relevant
The ingredients for making tofu are few,Irrelevant
They include the milk of soybeans water and coagulating agents,Irrelevant
The modern tofu manufacturing process is largely an automated version of the traditional method and much of the modern equipment is made in Japan,Irrelevant
While an individual tofu maker might work with 20 gallons (76 1) of beans at a time a contemporary processing facility can produce about 35 tons of tofu per day using 57 tons of soybeans,Irrelevant
The first step in making tofu is soaking the soybeans and extracting the milk,Relevant
A coagulant is added to curd the milk,Relevant
Traditionally the coagulant used is nigari which is a sea water precipitate rich in minerals such as magnesium and calcium chlorides,Relevant
But modern manufacturers use either calcium sulfate or magnesium chloride,Relevant
The soya curds are then processed into tofu in the desired form primarily in custardlike blocks,Relevant
A variety of textures may be produced depending on the water content,Irrelevant
Tofu comes in soft firm and extrafimn as well as silken or in liquid form,Irrelevant
A number of tofu flavors such as Jalapeno and Cheddar are also available,Irrelevant
Dried beans which come in 60pound (27 kg) sacks are soaked in water for 12 to 14 hours,Relevant
The beans soften as they absorb the water and double in size,Irrelevant
After soaking the beans are mashed with special Japanese stone grinders or other pureeing machines and mixed with water into a slurry,Relevant
The slurry is boiled to neutralize an enzyme that hinders digestion,Relevant
The soy milk is extracted with a roller press separating it from the pulp which consists of the hull and fiber,Relevant
This process may take about two hours to complete,Irrelevant
The remaining pulp can be used to feed livestock,Irrelevant
Once the whey is extracted the soybean juice is pumped into curding vats,Relevant
A coagulating agent is mixed in such as calcium sulfate magnesium chloride or nigari,Relevant
The coagulant alters the pH and curds the milk much like the process for making cottage cheese,Relevant
This step takes about 20 minutes,Irrelevant
Traditionally the curds are pressed with handturned screw presses or simple lever presses,Relevant
The tofu may be pressed in cheeseclothlined boxes,Relevant
Modern systems use centrifuges or hydraulic presses,Irrelevant
The whey drains off leaving soft blocks of pressed curds,Relevant
Tofu can be produced in a variety of textures from a dense cheeselike texture to a softer or liquid form,Irrelevant
Automated cutters slice the cake tofu into onepound (45 kg) blocks,Relevant
The tofu blocks are washed in vats of water where they firm up and are stored until they are ready to be processed further,Relevant
Tofu may be packaged into shrinkwrapped blocks or continuous thermoform packages,Relevant
Water may be added to the packages or tubs and then they are sealed weighed and dated,Relevant
Some companies process the soy milk directly in its package,Irrelevant
The packaged tofu is pasteurized at about 180°F (82°C),Relevant
Pasteurization extends the shelf life of tofu to about 30 days,Irrelevant
The tofu is then chilled in water until it is ready to be placed into boxes and shipped to distributors,Relevant
Tofu must be refrigerated at below 45°F (7°C) to keep it fresh,Relevant
Contemporary toothbrushes are produced mechanically,Irrelevant
Generally toothbrushes consist of plastic handles and nylon or natural boar bristles,Irrelevant
Plastic is mixed and shaped into pellets,Relevant
The pellets are then placed in an injection molding machine which heats the plastic until it is melted,Relevant
A rotating screw or plunger forces the liquid plastic into the handle molds,Relevant
The molds form the entire handle including the small holes called cores into which the bristles are inserted,Relevant
The molds are securely clamped and pressure is applied to the molds while the plastic cools,Relevant
Once the molds have adequately cooled the clamps are removed and small pins push the handles out of the molds,Relevant
The bristles which are usually made of nylon are positioned into the core of the handle automatically,Relevant
The bristles are then stapled into the core with tiny metal staples,Relevant
Next the toothbrush passes through a trimming machine which slices the bristles to the correct length and shape for the particular design,Relevant
The toothbrushes are packaged into cardboard andor plastic containers,Relevant
Labels are attached to the package providing product information such as bristle hardness as well as recommendations for usage,Relevant
If the brand is approved by the American Dental Association the Seal of Acceptance is also stamped on the container,Irrelevant
Finally the packaged toothbrushes are bundled into larger shipping boxes or crates and transported to distributors,Relevant
A traffic signal is fabricated in the manufacturers plant then installed and wired at the site of the intersection,Irrelevant
The housing or body of each signal stack is die cast as are the lens door and the bulb door which attach to the body,Irrelevant
They may be cast as individual housings and doors for each light or as larger units for each stack,Irrelevant
The diecasting process uses a large twopiece steel mold called a die,Irrelevant
Inside the mold called the cavity is the reverse image of the part to be cast,Irrelevant
The die is placed in a machine which clamps the two halves together with a force of 2400000 pounds (1090000 kg),Relevant
Molten aluminum is poured into the shot end of the die and a plunger rams the metal into the cavity under a pressure of approximately 2000 pounds per square inch (138 bar),Relevant
The molten metal is forced into every portion of the cavity and cools,Relevant
After about 15 seconds the die is opened and the hot part is ejected,Relevant
The part is then cooled for about 30 minutes,Relevant
Under normal conditions a diecasting machine like this can produce about 30 parts per hour,Irrelevant
Once the cast part is cooled it is trimmed,Irrelevant
The trimming process uses a stamping die to shear off any excess metal,Irrelevant
The part is then visually inspected and a hand file is used to remove any sharp burrs,Relevant
The points where the doors are to mount to the housing are machined to ensure they will fit properly,Irrelevant
The doors are attached to the housing with hinge pins and retained by spring latches,Relevant
If the housings and doors have been cast individually they are assembled to form the stack,Irrelevant
The holes used for fastening the stack to the support structure are drilled,Relevant
The stack is cleaned painted and placed in a drying oven,Relevant
The painted stack is transferred to a final assembly area where the lamps lampholders reflectors and lenses are installed,Relevant
Stainless steel screws and fasteners are used,Relevant
The lenses are sealed against the lampholder assembly with weatherproof gaskets,Relevant
The sheet metal visors which were fabricated in another operation are attached to each light,Relevant
Wiring from each light is routed through the hollow stack housing to the stack mounting point,Relevant
The housing for the electrical controller may be cast or fabricated,Relevant
It is trimmed machined and painted in much the same manner as the signal stack,Relevant
Inside it has mounting points to which the electrical control boards are attached,Relevant
The traffic signal manufacturer may assemble the electrical components or may have this done by another company,Relevant
The supports may be cast spun or fabricated,Relevant
Supports are hollow with an electrical junction box built into the base to connect with the wires coming underground from the controller,Relevant
Some supports include decorative details to make the signals fit in with the architecture of the surrounding area,Irrelevant
In some signal installations the light stacks are hung from heavy steel cables spanning the intersection,Irrelevant
Underground electrical conduits between the controller and each signal support location are put in place and connecting wires are pulled through the conduits,Irrelevant
Power for the signal is brought to the controller location,Relevant
If sensors are to be placed in the road they are connected to the controller as well,Relevant
The supports are bolted in place and wires are pulled through the hollow supports between the base and the signal stack mounting point,Relevant
The signal stacks are attached to the supports,Relevant
The wiring is then connected between all the elements of the system,Relevant

Each individual light is given a final adjustment to aim it properly the sequence timers in the controller are set to the specifications determined by the traffic engineers and the system is cycled several times to test for proper operation of each element,Relevant
Manufacturing an antivirus vaccine today is a complicated process even after the arduous task of creating a potential vaccine in the laboratory,Irrelevant

The change from manufacturing a potential vaccine in small quantities to manufacturing gallons of safe vaccine in a production situation is dramatic and simple laboratory procedure may not be amenable to a scale up situation,Irrelevant
Manufacturing begins with small amounts of a specific virus (or seed),Relevant
The virus must be free of impurities including other similar viruses and even variations of the same type of virus,Relevant
Additionally the seed must be kept under ideal conditions usually frozen that prevent the virus from becoming either stronger or weaker than desired,Relevant

Stored in small glass or plastic containers amounts as small as only 5 or 10 cubic centimeters but containing thousands if not millions of viruses will eventually lead to several hundred liters of vaccine,Relevant
Freezers are maintained at specified temperatures charts andor dials outside of the freezer keep a continuous record of the temperature,Irrelevant
Sensors will set off audible alarm signals andor computer alarms if the freezer temperature goes out of range,Irrelevant

After defrosting and warming the seed virus under carefully specified conditions (ie at room temperature or in a water bath) the small amount of virus cells is placed into a cell factory a small machine that with the addition of an appropriate medium allows the virus cells to multiply,Relevant

Each type of virus grows best in a medium specific to it established in premanufacturing laboratory procedures but all contain proteins from mammals in one form or another such as purified protein from cow blood,Irrelevant
The medium also contains other proteins and organic compounds that encourage the reproduction of the virus cells,Irrelevant
As far as the virus is concerned the medium in a cell factory is a host for reproduction,Irrelevant
Mixed with the appropriate medium at appropriate temperature and with a predetermined amount of time viruses will multiply,Irrelevant
In addition to temperature other factors must be monitored including the pH of the mixture,Irrelevant
pH is a measure of acidity or basicity measured on a scale from 0 to 14 and the viruses must be kept at a defined pH within the cell factory,Relevant
Plain water which is neither acidic or basic (neutral) has a pH of 7,Irrelevant
Although the container in which the cells are growing is not very large (perhaps the size of a 48 quart pot) there are an impressive number of valves tubes and sensors connected to it,Irrelevant

Sensors monitor pH and temperature and there are various connections for adding media or chemicals such as oxygen to maintain the pH places to withdraw samples for microscopic analysis and sterile arrangements for adding the components of the cell factory and withdrawing the intermediate product when it is ready,Irrelevant
The virus from the cell factory is then separated from the medium and placed in a second medium for additional growth,Relevant
Early methods of 40 or 50 years ago used a bottle to hold the mixture and the resulting growth was a single layer of viruses floating on the medium,Irrelevant
It was soon discovered that if the bottle was turned while the viruses were growing even more virus could be produced because a layer of virus grew on all inside surfaces of the bottle,Irrelevant
An important discovery in the 1940s was that cell growth is greatly stimulated by the addition of enzymes to a medium the most commonly used of which is trypsin,Irrelevant
An enzyme is a protein that also functions as a catalyst in the feeding and growth of cells,Irrelevant
In current practice bottles are not used at all,Irrelevant
The growing virus is kept in a container larger than but similar to the cell factory and mixed with beads near microscopic particles to which the viruses can attach themselves,Irrelevant
The use of the beads provides the virus with a much greater area to attach themselves to and consequently a much greater growth of virus,Relevant
As in the cell factory temperature and pH are strictly controlled,Relevant
Time spent in growing virus varies according to the type of virus being produced and is in each case a closely guarded secret of the manufacturer,Irrelevant
When there is a sufficient number of viruses they are separated from the beads in one or more ways,Relevant
The broth might be forced through a filter with openings large enough to allow the viruses to pass through but small enough to prevent the beads from passing,Relevant
The mixture might be centrifuged several times to separate the virus from the beads in a container from which they can then be drawn off,Relevant
Still another alternative might be to flood the bead mixture with another medium which washes the virus off the beads,Relevant
The eventual vaccine will be either made of attenuated (weakened) virus or a killed virus,Irrelevant
The choice of one or the other depends on a number of factors including the efficacy of the resulting vaccine and its secondary effects,Irrelevant
Ru vaccine which is developed almost every year in response to new variants of the causative virus is always an attenuated vaccine,Irrelevant
The virulence of a virus can dictate the choice rabies vaccine for example is always a killed vaccine,Irrelevant
If the vaccine is attenuated the virus is usually attenuated before it goes through the production process,Irrelevant
Carefully selected strains are cultured (grown) repeatedly in various media,Irrelevant
There are strains of viruses that actually become stronger as they grow,Irrelevant
These strains are clearly unusable for an attenuated vaccine,Irrelevant
Other strains become too weak as they are cultured repeatedly and these too are unacceptable for vaccine use,Irrelevant

Like the porridge chair and bed that Goldilocks liked only some viruses are just right reaching a level of attenuation that makes them acceptable for vaccine use and not changing in strength,Irrelevant
Recent molecular technology has made possible the attenuation of live virus by molecular manipulation but this method is still rare,Irrelevant
The virus is then separated from the medium in which it has been grown,Relevant
Vaccines which are of several types (as most are) are combined before packaging,Relevant
The actual amount of vaccine given to a patient will be relatively small compared with the medium in which it is given,Relevant
Decisions about whether to use water alcohol or some other solution for an injectable vaccine for example are made after repeated tests for safety sterility and stability,Relevant
The first step in making a violin is to make the sides (ribs) from which the outline of the top and back will be taken,Relevant
The ribs are constructed on an inside mold which is a wooden form about 15 to 18 mm thick cut to the exact outline of the inside of the violin,Relevant
Pieces of wood for the corner and end blocks are cut to approximate size and temporarily glued to cutouts on the mold at the proper locations,Relevant
With the aid of a pattern and using gouges and files the blocks are trimmed to the final shape of the inside contour of the violin,Relevant
Slices of maple slightly wider than the height of the ribs which are about 30 to 32 mm for a violin are cut and planed to a thickness of 1 mm,Relevant
Pieces are bent to the shape of the mold and blocks using a heated metal form,Relevant
After trimming to slightly longer than the final length the ribs are glued,Relevant
To hold the ribs in place until the glue dries countermolds shaped to match the outside contours of the ribs at the corners and ends are used,Relevant
Pressure is applied by clamps or wrapping with string,Relevant
Care must be taken to avoid gluing the ribs to the mold which must be removed in a subsequent step,Irrelevant
The ribs are glued in sequence starting with the middle bouts which must be trimmed to final length at the corners before the upper and lower ribs can be added,Relevant
The linings strips of willow or spruce about 2 by 8 mm are bent to shape using the bending iron cut to length and glued to the inside of the ribs,Relevant
The corners are trimmed to their final shape and the top and bottom surfaces of the ribs linings and blocks are planed and filed to be level at the final height,Relevant
The tops of violins are almost always made from a wedge of wood which is cut or split with the edges of resulting pieces glued together,Relevant
This joint for which the pieces must fit with absolute perfection then becomes the centerline of the top,Relevant
Maple for the backs of violins is treated the same way to make a twopiece back however it is possible to find a piece wide enough to make a onepiece back,Relevant
Planing the wood to create a perfect center joint is an exacting task,Irrelevant
After the pieces have been planed to fit well—as seen by holding the pieces together in front of a light—the edge of one piece is coated with chalk and rubbed against the mating edge,Relevant
The areas in which chalk is transferred from one piece to the other identify places which must be shaved slightly with the plane to perfect the fit,Relevant
This chalk fitting procedure is repeated until the fit between the two pieces is perfect after which they are glued together and clamped,Relevant
After gluing the center joint the flat side of the back and top are planed flat,Relevant
The ribs are placed on this flat side a tracing around the ribs enlarged by 3 mm establishes the outline of the top or back (a 20 mm square is added at the top of the back for the button),Relevant
These outlines are cut out using a bow or coping saw many modern violin makers use a power band or scroll saw,Relevant
The outside arching of the top and back are next carved using gouges thumb planes and scrapers for the final smoothing,Relevant
Five transverse and one longitudinal arching guides are consulted frequently as the plates take shape,Relevant
The arching guides which are different for the top and back plus the outline embodied in the mold determine the design or model of the instrument,Irrelevant
Most modern makers follow or copy the designs of great makers such as Stradivari or Guameri while some have evolved their own,Irrelevant
Next the interior sides of the top and back are carved out,Relevant

The final thicknesses of the wood has a major influence on the acoustic performance of the finished instrument and there are many systems in use for arriving at the optimum distribution of thicknesses,Irrelevant

In general most methods involve testing the resonance frequencies of the plates by tapping flexing or exciting them with sound coupled with measurements of the thickness of the plate at many locations using a graduation caliper,Irrelevant
Then depending on the results and on the desired outcome wood is gradually removed from various locations,Relevant
Usually makers seek to establish certain relationships eg octaves between the various resonances of each plate and between the two plates,Irrelevant
Typical thicknesses of a finished back are 45 mm at the center decreasing to 24 to 25 mm in the upper and lower bouts,Irrelevant
The thicknesses of the top are more uniform about 3 mm overall and perhaps slightly thicker between the soundholes in the area of the soundpost,Irrelevant
The outline of the sound holes is transferred to the top and these are cut out using a sharp knife some makers use a punch or drill to cut the round holes,Relevant
The bassbar is made of very straight grained quartercut spruce (much like the top),Relevant
The area where it fits is outlined on the side of the top and the rough blank is trimmed to precisely fit the arching,Relevant
The chalkfitting method is employed again in this step,Irrelevant
The bar is then glued in place and trimmed to its final contour,Relevant
This again involves testing the resonance of the top which was altered by the cutting of the sound holes as well as the addition of the bassbar,Irrelevant
The mold is now removed from the rib assembly by loosening the temporary glue bonds of the blocks to the mold,Relevant
The top and back are then glued to the ribs,Relevant
The glue holding the back should be fullstrength,Relevant

Thinner weaker glue is used for the top this provides for easy removal if service or adjustment is necessary and will allow the seams to open in extremes of humidity and temperature rather than produce cracks in the wood itself,Relevant
The groove for the purfling is marked a precise distance from the edges using a purfling cutter,Relevant
The groove is deepened with a sharp knife and the wood in the groove removed with a purfling pick,Relevant
The purfling strips which can be bought ready or made by the violin maker are bent to fit the groove using the bending iron,Relevant
The pieces are then cut to the exact length mitered to fit the corners and glued in place,Relevant
The channels which run over the purfling just inside the edges are cut with a gouge and blended into the arching with gouge planes and scrapers,Irrelevant
Finally the edge is rounded using knife file and perhaps sandpaper,Relevant
(This is one of the only places in which sandpaper is used in the construction of a violin),Irrelevant
All of the other surfaces should be finished with scrapers which provides a crisp appearance to the workmanship and best reveals the beauty of the wood,Irrelevant
A block of maple matching the back is squared on the sides and top with a plane,Irrelevant
Next the outline of the side view of the neck and scroll is traced on the quartercut side of the block,Relevant
The wood outside the outline is sawed away,Relevant
Patterns and outlines for the peg box top surface of the neck and the scroll are traced,Relevant
A razor saw is then used to cut away wood around the scroll and neck outlines,Relevant
Gouges and scrapers are used to finish the carving of the scroll the details of which are one of the ways in which the violin maker expresses his individuality,Relevant
The pegbox is excavated using chisels and gouges,Relevant
The neck is cut to final dimensions using planes knives and scrapers,Relevant
A mortise (cavity) to receive the neck is cut into the upper ribs block and top of the violins body,Relevant
The cut of the mortise and the root of the neck must be very precise since the correct height and angle of the neck are critical to achieving a good tonal result,Relevant
Chalk fitting is again employed,Relevant
The neck is then glued into the mortise and the final shaping of the heel of the neck and the button on the back is done,Relevant
There is a great deal of lore associated with the varnishing of violins,Irrelevant
It has even been asserted that secret recipes are responsible for the extraordinary tonal characteristics of the old Italian violins,Relevant

Regardless of its possible effects on tone it is certainly true that the varnish does serve other important purposes of beautifying the appearance and protecting the wood from wear damage moisture and dirt,Irrelevant
Thus the selection and application of varnish is vitally important,Relevant

Because there are many types of varnish and working methods the following rather general outline of finishing is provided The finished violin is hung up to age for a time (in some cases several months or more) and may be exposed to sunlight,Relevant
This will cause the wood to darken and bring out its figure,Relevant
Many makers use less timeconsuming alternatives,Irrelevant
The vamish is applied in several coats,Relevant
This may include coats of clear vamish followed by additional coats of colored varnish,Irrelevant
Vamish is essentially a coating consisting of resins which may be natural substances (eg copal or seedlac) or manmade,Irrelevant
Color is imparted to vamishes by adding pigments or dyes,Relevant
The color of the individual coats may be varied to produce the desired appearance,Relevant
Following the colored vamish an additional coat or two of clear vamish may be applied to protect the layers underneath,Relevant
Since oldlooking violins are more appealing to many players some makers antique their instruments,Irrelevant
The various methods of antiquing are usually trade secrets and makers pride themselves on their individual results,Irrelevant
The surface of the fully dried vamish may be rubbed out using some combination of abrasives (pumice rottenstone fine emery paper etc) and polishes,Irrelevant
The part of the neck between the heel and the peg box is not varnished,Irrelevant
Rather it is stained sanded very smooth with fine emery paper and french polished (an application of shellac andor alcohol and oil),Irrelevant
The top of the neck is planed flat and the underside of the ebony fmgerboard is planed to fit and glued in place,Relevant
The sides and top are finished with planes scrapers and emery paper to be smooth and to have exactly the correct curvature,Relevant
Gauges and straightedge are consulted frequently during this process,Relevant
The ebony nut is cut to size lightly glued at the top of the fingerboard dressed to final shape and grooves filed for the strings,Relevant
A mortise is cut at the bottom of the violin into which is glued the ebony saddle,Relevant
The pegs are shaved to the proper taper and diameter,Relevant
Peg holes are drilled and reamed to match the pegs,Relevant
Likewise a hole at the bottom of the ribs is drilled reamed and fitted with the end pin,Relevant
The bridge and soundpost are the last parts to be fashioned their fit and position greatly affect the sound and playing qualities of the violin,Relevant
Starting with a precut blank the feet of the bridge are cut to fit the arching of the top at the proper position—between the nicks of the soundholes,Relevant
The top of the bridge is cut to an arch which matches the curvature of the fmgerboard and provides the proper height of the strings,Relevant
The front side (facing the neck) is planed down to a thickness of about 45 mm at the bottom and tapering from the middle to 15 mm at the top,Relevant
Grooves for the strings are cut and filed using a gauge to establish their proper position and spacing,Relevant
The soundpost transmits the vibrations of the strings to the back of the violin,Relevant
It is cut from a round piece of straightgrained spruce about 6 mm in diameter,Relevant
Its length and ends must be cut so that it fits precisely in the proper location inside the violin about 3 mm behind the treble foot of the bridge,Relevant
A gauge may be used to measure the approximate length of the soundpost but the final fit is a trial and error process,Irrelevant
The soundpost is inserted and its position adjusted through the soundholes using a special tool,Relevant
The strings are now fitted into the tailpiece extended over the bridge and wound on the pegs,Relevant
Once all four strings are installed they may be tuned up to pitch and the violin played for the first time,Relevant
What follows will be a period of adjustment as the violin becomes accustomed to the tension of the strings and their vibration,Relevant
Numerous adjustments to the position of the soundpost the bridge types of strings and perhaps other factors are usually necessary to optimize the tonal characteristics and playability,Relevant
Roughing the stick refers to the process of carving and planing the stick to its approximate finished dimensions,Irrelevant

The squared off blank of Pemnambuco wood is either held across the corner of a bench or along the length of a special board and planed by hand with specially designed planes fashioning the stick into its characteristic octagon shape,Irrelevant
Using a direct heat device such as a spirit lamp or gas burner the stick is heated slowly until it becomes flexible enough to bend,Relevant
When ready the stick is bent into an approximate or rough curve,Relevant
When cooled the stick is set aside and the work on the frog begins,Relevant
The frog begins with the fashioning of the metal fittings,Relevant
Several parts require soldering as well as bending and shaping,Relevant
The ferrule much like a half round ring is a semicircular length of sheet silver soldered to a flat one,Irrelevant
The button for the adjuster needs one or two silver rings,Irrelevant
The other metal parts include a silver liner which is shaped to three facets of an octagon on a steel die to conform to the three facets on which it will contact the stick,Irrelevant
If the frog is designed with a back plate the plate is shaped and bent to the 90 degree angle of the back of the frog where it is to be inlaid,Irrelevant
The ebony wedge is trimmed to length and planed true to its center on all sides with a small razor sharp block plane,Relevant
The various metal fittings are fit onto the frog in their respective places,Relevant
Although modern commercial manufacture uses milling machinery to accomplish this part the best modern builders have no problem doing this work by hand,Irrelevant
The fitting of the metal to the frog begins with drilling a 3mm hole called the throat just under the area where the ferrule is located,Relevant
The ferrule is fit onto the wider part of the throat with a knife and small chisels until it fits back flush and level,Irrelevant
The sides are shaped concave with a gouge,Relevant
The slot for the pearl slide with its 20 degree undercut sides is next to be shaved out with the chisels,Relevant
The cavity for the hair called the hair mortise is drilled and carved into the frog with a bow drill and chisel,Relevant
The liner is then fit to the narrow edge of the frogs length using the chisels,Relevant
The liner conformns to the top three facets of the sticks octagonal shape and is the bearing surface of the frog against the stick,Irrelevant
A tapered silver backplate extending from the back of the pearl slide slot to the center facet of the liner is inlaid to the flat end of the frog,Relevant
The frog is then shaped using a knife files and small scrapers made of thin steel sheet,Relevant
The decorations called the eyes are inlaid into the sides of the frog at this point,Relevant
Then the ebony dowel for the adjuster button is fashioned separately on a lathe,Relevant
After the frog is done the next job is to fit it to the roughed out stick,Relevant
This is done by chalking the liner of the frog and rubbing it against the facets of the stick at the point where the frog makes contact,Relevant
Through a process of marking the stick in this way and carefully planing scraping and filing the marks away the frog is brought into the proper contact with the three bottom facets,Relevant
Then holes are drilled in the stick for the screw and eye assembly which attaches the frog to the brass nut at the end of the stick,Relevant
The first step here is to fit an ivory plate to the head or tip of the bow,Relevant
A plate of ivory is prepared with a raised section for the right angle of the beak with a thin lamination of ebony veneer all along its inside surface,Relevant
The ivory is glued to the bottom face of the head,Relevant
The shaping of the head is done with a knife and files,Relevant
This work usually follows an established model and is accomplished with the means of a pattern or template which is alternately traced and compared with the carving as it progresses,Irrelevant
The elegant head models of the classic bows are often very beautiful and have inspired connoisseurs the world over to collect them,Irrelevant

All the great bowmakers imprinted their work with their own personal style and experts are easily able to recognize most of the important styles each head being akin to the signature of the maker,Irrelevant
Once the head is finished the mortise for the hair is cut into it and the finishing of the stick can continue,Relevant
The stick must be now brought into final dimension a process called graduation,Relevant
The stick tapers from 3443210 mm just behind the head to 6444135 mm at the button end,Relevant
Using a gauge or caliper the craftsman skillfully planes this transition of thickness into the stick,Relevant
The whole process must be done while preserving the integrity of a perfect octagon,Relevant

The octagons transition into the head is most difficult and ends with the top three facets converging upwards the two side facets becoming the side of the head and the bottom three becoming the back of the head and the chamfers (a thin finish cut at a 45 degree angle to the sides),Relevant
All of this work is accomplished with either the plane in the case of the facets or the knife and file for the detailing of the head,Irrelevant
The stick is simply held by hand across a flat board or the corner of the workbench while planing the facets,Irrelevant
The head is simply held in the hand while finishing,Irrelevant

If the stick is to be finished round as many are the edges of the octagon are planed away after graduation and the stick is rounded off in this manner to an area about 14423 34 inches (46 cm) in front of the frog,Irrelevant
The area where one holds the bow is almost always octagonal,Irrelevant
The bow usually has no real varnish as such because Pernambuco is inherently dark and oily,Irrelevant
But the stick may be subjected to a number of chemical treatments to achieve its characteristic chocolate brown color,Irrelevant
Bathing the stick with nitric acid and then following with a neutralizing exposure to ammonia fumes is the most common color treatment,Relevant
The bow is given additional sheen and protection by a technique known as French polishing,Irrelevant

This involves the application of a dilute solution of shellac sometimes mixed with other gums or resins with a lightly oiled rag held wrapped around the fingers The roughing and finishing of bow sticks do not vary in technique from hand making to commercial manufacture Most violin bows are made completely by hand Only the speed of production quality of materials and diligence in finishing distinguish the difference between the mediocre and the sublime 6 The lapping or winding acts as a grip for the stick and is often called the grip,Relevant
It usually covers a 3inch (76 cm) length starting from just in front of the frog and going toward the tip,Irrelevant
It consists of some material usually silver wire wound in a compact spiral fashion around the stick,Irrelevant
Part of the winding nearest the frog is covered with leather to protect the spot where the players thumb rests,Relevant
The hairing of the bow is quite routine as the hair wears from playing and must be frequently replaced,Relevant
The horsehair is purchased already selected drawn and bundled in uniform lengths,Relevant
A small amount is separated from this and a small rosined knot is fashioned at one end using very strong thin thread,Relevant
The knot is made stronger by inserting the end of the hair into the heat of a flame and expanding the hair behind it,Relevant

A small wooden plug is carved to fit the mortise in the head and the hair is turned under and fastened into the head with this plug which holds the hair spread across the top edge in a neat uniform flat strip,Relevant
With the frog all the way forward the hair is measured to length cut off and after much combing and arranging tied in a similar way at the end near the frog,Relevant
Another wooden plug is fashioned for the mortise of the frog,Relevant
The ferrule is slid over the hair and after much more combing the hair is turned over and fastened again with a wooden plug this time into the frog,Relevant
The hair is combed again before pushing in the pearl slide and again after sliding on the ferrule,Relevant
A wooden wedge is carved to fit the width of the ferrule so as to hold the hair spread in a ribbonlike fashion,Relevant
After some more combing the wedge is pushed into the ferrule against the hair and trimmed off with a knife,Relevant
With the application of some rosin on the hair for grip the new bow is ready to play,Relevant
Truckloads of grain are shipped directly from farms to the whiskey manufacturer to be stored in silos until needed,Irrelevant
The grain is inspected and cleaned to remove all dust and other foreign particles,Relevant
All grains except barley are first ground into meal in a gristmill,Relevant
The meal is then mixed with water and cooked to break down the cellulose walls that contain starch granules,Relevant
This can be done in a closed pressure cooker at temperatures of up to 311°F (155°C) or more slowly in an open cooker at 212°F (100°C),Relevant
Instead of being cooked barley is malted,Relevant
The first step in malting barley consists of soaking it in water until it is thoroughly saturated,Relevant
It is then spread out and sprinkled with water for about three weeks at which time it begins to sprout,Relevant
During this germination the enzyme amylase is produced which converts the starch in the barley into sugars,Relevant
The sprouting is halted by drying the barley and heating it with hot air from a kiln,Relevant
For Scotch whiskey the fuel used in the kiln includes peat a soft carbonrich substance formed when plant matter decomposes in water,Irrelevant
The peat gives Scotch whiskey a characteristic smoky taste,Irrelevant
The malted barley is then ground like other grains,Relevant
Mashing consists of mixing cooked grain with malted barley and warm water,Irrelevant
The amylase in the malted barley converts the starch in the other grains into sugars,Relevant
After several hours the mixture is converted into a turbid sugarrich liquid known as mash,Relevant
(In making Scotch malt whiskey the mixture consists only of malted barley and water),Irrelevant
After mashing the mixture is filtered to produce a sugarrich liquid known as wort,Relevant
The mash or wort is transferred to a fermentation vessel usually closed in Scotland and open in the United States,Relevant
These vessels may be made of wood or stainless steel,Relevant
Yeast is added to begin fermentation in which the singlecelled yeast organisms convert the sugars in the mash or wort to alcohol,Relevant
The yeast may be added in the form of new neverused yeast cells (the sweet mash process) or in the form of a portion of a previous batch of fermentation (the sour mash process),Irrelevant
The sour mash method is more often used because it is effective at room temperature and its low pH (high acidity) promotes yeast growth and inhibits the growth of bacteria,Irrelevant
The sweet mash method is more difficult to control and it must be used at temperatures above 80°F (27°C) to speed up the fermentation and to avoid bacterial contamination,Irrelevant
After three or four days the end product of fermentation is a liquid containing about 10 alcohol known as distillers beer in the United States or wash in Scotland,Irrelevant
Scottish whiskeymakers often distill their wash in traditional copper pot stills,Irrelevant
The wash is heated so that most of the alcohol (which boils at 172°F [78°C]) is transformed into vapor but most of the water (which boils at 212°F [100°C]) is not,Relevant
This vapor is transferred back into liquid alcohol in a watercooled condenser and collected,Relevant
Most modern distilleries use a continuous still,Irrelevant
This consists of a tall cylindrical column filled with a series of perforated plates,Irrelevant
Steam enters the still from the bottom and distillers beer enters from the top,Irrelevant
The beer is distilled as it slowly drips through the plates and the alcohol is condensed back into a liquid,Relevant

With either method the product of the initial distillation—known as low wine—is distilled a second time to produce a product known as high wine or new whiskey which contains about 70 alcohol,Irrelevant
The temperature of distillation and other factors determine the proportions of water alcohol and other substances (called congeners) in the final product,Irrelevant
If it contains more than 95 alcohol it will have no flavor because it has no congeners,Irrelevant
This product is known as grain neutral spirit and is often used to add alcohol without adding taste during blending,Irrelevant
If the final product has too many congeners of the wrong kind it will taste bad,Irrelevant
Distillers remove badtasting congeners (usually aldehydes acids esters and higher alcohols) in various ways,Irrelevant
Some congeners boil at a lower temperature than alcohol and can be boiled off,Irrelevant
Some are lighter than alcohol and will float on top where they can be poured off,Irrelevant
Tennessee whiskey is unique in that the high wine is filtered through charcoal before it is aged,Irrelevant
The charcoal is produced by burnning wood from sugar maples,Irrelevant
This filtration removes unwanted congeners and results in a particularly smooth whiskey,Irrelevant
Premium Tennessee whiskey may be filtered through charcoal again after it is aged to produce an even smoother product,Irrelevant
Water is added to the high wine to reduce its alcohol content to about 50 or 60 for American whiskeys and about 65 or higher for Scotch whiskeys,Irrelevant
Scotch whiskeys are aged in cool wet conditions so they absorb water and become less alcoholic,Irrelevant
American whiskeys are aged in warmer drier conditions so they lose water and become more alcoholic,Irrelevant
Whiskey is aged in wooden barrels usually made from charred white oak,Irrelevant

White oak is used because it is one of the few woods that can hold a liquid without leaking but which also allows the water in the whiskey to move back and forth within the pores of the wood which helps to add flavor,Irrelevant
In the United States these barrels are usually new and are only used once,Irrelevant
In most other countries it is common to reuse old barrels,Irrelevant
New barrels add more flavor than used barrels resulting in differences in the taste of American and foreign whiskeys,Irrelevant
The aging process is a complex one still not fully understood but at least three factors are involved,Irrelevant
First the original mixture of water alcohol and congeners react with each other over time,Irrelevant
Second these ingredients react with oxygen in the outside air in oxidation reactions,Irrelevant
Third the water absorbs substances from the wood as it moves within it,Irrelevant
(Charring the wood makes these substances more soluble in water),Irrelevant
All these factors change the flavor of the whiskey,Irrelevant
Whiskey generally takes at least three or four years to mature and many whiskeys are aged for ten or fifteen years,Irrelevant
Straight whiskeys and single malt Scotch whiskeys are not blended that is they are produced from single batches and are ready to be bottled straight from the barrel,Irrelevant
All other whiskeys are blended,Irrelevant
Different batches of whiskey are mixed together to produce a better flavor,Relevant
Often neutral grain spirit is added to lighten the flavor caramel is added to standardize the color and a small amount of sherry or port wine is added to help the flavors blend,Irrelevant
Blended Scotch whiskey usually consists of several batches of strongly flavored malt whiskeys mixed with less strongly flavored grain whiskeys,Irrelevant
A few blends contain only malt whiskeys,Irrelevant
Blending is often considered the most difficult and critical process in producing premium Scotch whiskeys,Irrelevant
A premium blended Scotch whiskey may contain more than 60 individual malt whiskeys which must be blended in the proper proportions,Irrelevant
Glass is always used to store mature whiskey because it does not react with it to change the flavor,Irrelevant
Modern distilleries use automated machinery to produce as many as 400 bottles of whiskey per minute,Irrelevant
The glass bottles move down a conveyor belt as they are cleaned filled capped sealed labeled and placed in cardboard boxes,Relevant
The whiskey is ready to be shipped to liquor stores bars and restaurants,Relevant
Truckloads of grain are shipped directly from farms to the whiskey manufacturer to be stored in silos until needed,Irrelevant
The grain is inspected and cleaned to remove all dust and other foreign particles,Relevant
All grains except barley are first ground into meal in a gristmill,Relevant
The meal is then mixed with water and cooked to break down the cellulose walls that contain starch granules,Relevant
This can be done in a closed pressure cooker at temperatures of up to 311°F (155°C) or more slowly in an open cooker at 212°F (100°C),Relevant
Instead of being cooked barley is malted,Relevant
The first step in malting barley consists of soaking it in water until it is thoroughly saturated,Relevant
It is then spread out and sprinkled with water for about three weeks at which time it begins to sprout,Relevant
During this germination the enzyme amylase is produced which converts the starch in the barley into sugars,Relevant
The sprouting is halted by drying the barley and heating it with hot air from a kiln,Relevant
For Scotch whiskey the fuel used in the kiln includes peat a soft carbonrich substance formed when plant matter decomposes in water,Irrelevant
The peat gives Scotch whiskey a characteristic smoky taste,Irrelevant
The malted barley is then ground like other grains,Relevant
Mashing consists of mixing cooked grain with malted barley and warm water,Irrelevant
The amylase in the malted barley converts the starch in the other grains into sugars,Relevant
After several hours the mixture is converted into a turbid sugarrich liquid known as mash,Relevant
(In making Scotch malt whiskey the mixture consists only of malted barley and water),Irrelevant
After mashing the mixture is filtered to produce a sugarrich liquid known as wort,Relevant
The mash or wort is transferred to a fermentation vessel usually closed in Scotland and open in the United States,Relevant
These vessels may be made of wood or stainless steel,Relevant
Yeast is added to begin fermentation in which the singlecelled yeast organisms convert the sugars in the mash or wort to alcohol,Relevant
The yeast may be added in the form of new neverused yeast cells (the sweet mash process) or in the form of a portion of a previous batch of fermentation (the sour mash process),Irrelevant
The sour mash method is more often used because it is effective at room temperature and its low pH (high acidity) promotes yeast growth and inhibits the growth of bacteria,Irrelevant
The sweet mash method is more difficult to control and it must be used at temperatures above 80°F (27°C) to speed up the fermentation and to avoid bacterial contamination,Irrelevant
After three or four days the end product of fermentation is a liquid containing about 10 alcohol known as distillers beer in the United States or wash in Scotland,Irrelevant
Scottish whiskeymakers often distill their wash in traditional copper pot stills,Irrelevant
The wash is heated so that most of the alcohol (which boils at 172°F [78°C]) is transformed into vapor but most of the water (which boils at 212°F [100°C]) is not,Relevant
This vapor is transferred back into liquid alcohol in a watercooled condenser and collected,Relevant
Most modern distilleries use a continuous still,Irrelevant
This consists of a tall cylindrical column filled with a series of perforated plates,Irrelevant
Steam enters the still from the bottom and distillers beer enters from the top,Irrelevant
The beer is distilled as it slowly drips through the plates and the alcohol is condensed back into a liquid,Relevant

With either method the product of the initial distillation—known as low wine—is distilled a second time to produce a product known as high wine or new whiskey which contains about 70 alcohol,Irrelevant
The temperature of distillation and other factors determine the proportions of water alcohol and other substances (called congeners) in the final product,Irrelevant
If it contains more than 95 alcohol it will have no flavor because it has no congeners,Irrelevant
This product is known as grain neutral spirit and is often used to add alcohol without adding taste during blending,Irrelevant
If the final product has too many congeners of the wrong kind it will taste bad,Irrelevant
Distillers remove badtasting congeners (usually aldehydes acids esters and higher alcohols) in various ways,Irrelevant
Some congeners boil at a lower temperature than alcohol and can be boiled off,Irrelevant
Some are lighter than alcohol and will float on top where they can be poured off,Irrelevant
Tennessee whiskey is unique in that the high wine is filtered through charcoal before it is aged,Irrelevant
The charcoal is produced by burnning wood from sugar maples,Irrelevant
This filtration removes unwanted congeners and results in a particularly smooth whiskey,Irrelevant
Premium Tennessee whiskey may be filtered through charcoal again after it is aged to produce an even smoother product,Irrelevant
Water is added to the high wine to reduce its alcohol content to about 50 or 60 for American whiskeys and about 65 or higher for Scotch whiskeys,Irrelevant
Scotch whiskeys are aged in cool wet conditions so they absorb water and become less alcoholic,Irrelevant
American whiskeys are aged in warmer drier conditions so they lose water and become more alcoholic,Irrelevant
Whiskey is aged in wooden barrels usually made from charred white oak,Irrelevant

White oak is used because it is one of the few woods that can hold a liquid without leaking but which also allows the water in the whiskey to move back and forth within the pores of the wood which helps to add flavor,Irrelevant
In the United States these barrels are usually new and are only used once,Irrelevant
In most other countries it is common to reuse old barrels,Irrelevant
New barrels add more flavor than used barrels resulting in differences in the taste of American and foreign whiskeys,Irrelevant
The aging process is a complex one still not fully understood but at least three factors are involved,Irrelevant
First the original mixture of water alcohol and congeners react with each other over time,Irrelevant
Second these ingredients react with oxygen in the outside air in oxidation reactions,Irrelevant
Third the water absorbs substances from the wood as it moves within it,Irrelevant
(Charring the wood makes these substances more soluble in water),Irrelevant
All these factors change the flavor of the whiskey,Irrelevant
Whiskey generally takes at least three or four years to mature and many whiskeys are aged for ten or fifteen years,Irrelevant
